context: If you had told me several months ago, immediately after Elon Musk bought Twitter and Ron DeSantis celebrated a thumping re-election victory, that DeSantis would launch his presidential campaign in conversation with Musk, I would have thought, intriguing: The rightward-trending billionaire whose rockets and cars stand out in an economy dominated by apps and financial instruments meets the Republican politician whose real-world victories contrast with the virtual populism of Donald Trump.

The actual launch of DeSantis’s presidential campaign, in a “Twitter Spaces” event that crashed repeatedly and played to a smaller audience than he would have claimed just by showing up on Fox, instead offered the political version of the lesson that we’ve been taught repeatedly by Musk’s stewardship of Twitter: The internet can be a trap.

For the Tesla and SpaceX mogul, the trap was sprung because Musk wanted to attack the groupthink of liberal institutions, and seeing that groupthink manifest on his favorite social media site, he imagined that owning Twitter was the key to transforming public discourse.

But for all its influence, social media is still downstream of other institutions — universities, newspapers, television channels, movie studios, other internet platforms. Twitter is real life, but only through its relationship to other realities; it doesn’t have the capacity to be a hub of discourse, news gathering or entertainment on its own. And many of Musk’s difficulties as the Twitter C.E.O. have reflected a simple overestimation of social media’s inherent authority and influence.

Thus he’s tried to sell the privilege of verification, the famous “blue checks,” without recognizing that they were valued because of their connection to real-world institutions and lose value if they reflect a Twitter hierarchy alone. Or he’s encouraged his favored journalists to publish their scoops and essays on his site when it isn’t yet built out for that kind of publication. Or he’s encouraged media figures like Tucker Carlson and now politicians like DeSantis to run shows or do interviews on his platform, without having the infrastructure in place to make all that work.

It’s entirely possible that Musk can build out that infrastructure eventually, and make Twitter more capacious than it is today. But there isn’t some immediate social-media shortcut to the influence he’s seeking. If you want Twitter to be the world’s news hub, you probably need a Twitter newsroom. If you want Twitter to host presidential candidates, you probably need a Twitter channel that feels like a professional newscast. And while you’re trying to build those things, you need to be careful that the nature of social media doesn’t diminish you to the kind of caricatured role — troll instead of tycoon — that tempts everyone on Twitter.

That kind of diminishment is what the Twitter event handed to DeSantis, whose choppy launch may be forgotten but who would be wise to learn from what went wrong. There’s an emerging criticism of the Florida governor that suggests that his whole persona is too online — that his talk about wokeness, wokeness, wokeness is pitched to a narrow and internet-based faction within the G.O.P., that he’s setting himself to be like Elizabeth Warren in 2020, whose promise of plans, plans, plans thrilled the wonk faction but fell flat with normal Democratic voters.

I think this critique is overdrawn. If you look at polling of Republican primary voters, the culture war appears to be a general concern rather than an elite fixation, and there’s a plausible argument that the conflict with the new progressivism is the main thing binding the G.O.P. coalition together.

But it does seem true that the conflict with progressivism in the context of social media is a more boutique taste, and that lots of anti-woke conservatives aren’t particularly invested in whether the previous Twitter regime was throttling such-and-such right-wing influencer or taking orders from such-and-such “disinformation” specialist. And it’s also true that DeSantis is running against a candidate who, at any moment, can return to Twitter and bestride its feeds like a colossus, no matter whatever Republican alternative the “chief twit” might prefer.

So introducing himself in that online space made DeSantis look unnecessarily small — smaller than Musk’s presence and Trump’s absence, shrunk down to the scale of debates about shadow banning and Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act. The Florida governor’s best self-advertisement in a primary should be his promise to be more active in reality than Trump, with his claim to be better at actual governance made manifest through his advantage in flesh-pressing, campaign-trail-hitting energy.

The good news for DeSantis is that he doesn’t have billions invested in a social media company, so having endured a diminishing introduction, he can slip the trap and walk away — toward the crowds, klieg lights and the grass.
For Musk, though, escape requires either the admission of defeat in this particular arena or else a long campaign of innovation that eventually makes Twitter as big as he wrongly imagined it to be.

question: 3. What is the author's opinion on the use of social media in politics?
close_book_answer: The author's opinion on the use of social media in politics is a complex one. On one hand, the author acknowledges the potential benefits of social media in political discourse, such as its ability to provide a platform for marginalized voices and to facilitate political mobilization. However, the author also recognizes the negative consequences of social media use in politics, such as the spread of misinformation and the amplification of polarizing views.

One key claim the author makes is that social media can be a powerful tool for political engagement, particularly for marginalized groups who may not have had access to traditional media outlets. The author cites examples of social media campaigns that have successfully mobilized people around specific political issues, such as Black Lives Matter and the #MeToo movement. However, the author also acknowledges that social media can amplify extremist views and contribute to the spread of misinformation.

Another claim the author makes is that social media use in politics can have unintended consequences, particularly when it comes to the spread of misinformation. The author notes that social media algorithms can amplify certain types of content, such as sensationalist or emotional content, which can contribute to the spread of false information. Additionally, the author argues that social media use can contribute to the polarization of political discourse, as people are more likely to engage with content that confirms their existing beliefs rather than challenging them.

Overall, the author's opinion on the use of social media in politics is nuanced, recognizing both the potential benefits and drawbacks of social media use. The author argues that while social media can be a powerful tool for political engagement, it is important to be aware of the potential negative consequences and to take steps to mitigate them.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Social media can have potential benefits in political discourse, such as providing a platform for marginalized voices and facilitating political mobilization.
2. Social media can also have negative consequences, including the spread of misinformation and the amplification of polarizing views.
3. Social media can be a powerful tool for political engagement, particularly for marginalized groups who may not have had access to traditional media outlets.
4. Social media can amplify extremist views and contribute to the spread of misinformation.
5. It is important to be aware of the potential negative consequences of social media use in politics and take steps to mitigate them.

The author suggests that social media has both positive and negative effects on public discourse.

On the one hand, social media allows people to access a diverse range of opinions and perspectives, which can broaden their understanding of complex issues. Social media also provides a platform for marginalized groups to have their voices heard and to challenge dominant narratives. In this way, social media can be seen as a powerful tool for promoting social change and for holding those in power accountable.

On the other hand, the author argues that social media can also perpetuate misinformation and harmful content, which can distort public discourse and undermine trust in the media. The author suggests that social media algorithms can reinforce echo chambers, where people only encounter information that confirms their existing beliefs, and that this can lead to a polarization of public opinion.

In conclusion, the author views social media as having a complex and multifaceted role in shaping public discourse. While social media can be a powerful tool for promoting social change and for broadening our understanding of complex issues, it can also perpetuate misinformation and harmful content, which can distort public discourse and undermine trust in the media.

context: Every year the Federal Reserve takes a financial snapshot of America. It tells us how people are making ends meet, or not. Whether they’re (still) living with their parents, if they’ve saved money for retirement, whether they wish they had chosen a different major in college and so on.

Last year’s Survey of Household Economics and Decisionmaking, as the Fed calls it, covered 11,667 U.S. adults and was conducted online from Oct. 21 through Nov. 1. There are breakdowns by age, income, race and gender. Considering that there are no anecdotes and the writing is reserved, the Fed’s report on the survey, “Economic Well-Being of U.S. Households in 2022,” is a surprisingly human document.

The report, which was released on Monday, portrays a nation that is enjoying a strong job market but is unhappy about inflation. Most people feel at least OK about their personal situations but are down on the national economic situation. If I were sitting in the Oval Office right now, I would be concerned about the public’s fairly gloomy answers.

I’ll start with the chart that has the most political valence. It shows that the share of people who say they’re doing “at least OK” financially has been remarkably stable since 2017, at around three-quarters. The pandemic recession isn’t visible in the numbers. In contrast to that self-assessment, the share who say the national economy is good or excellent has fallen sharply, to just 18 percent last year from 41 percent in 2017.

True, some people may perceive “good or excellent” to be a tougher standard than “at least OK,” so you might expect the numbers on the national economy to be lower. What’s surprising (and bad for incumbent politicians) is that the gap in perceptions between the personal and the national has widened so much, to 55 percentage points last year from 25 percentage points in 2019.

People are comparison machines — we compare ourselves with others and with ourselves at different times — so maybe one reason for the gloomy appraisal of the national situation is that people feel things have been going in the wrong direction lately. When asked about their financial situations compared with 12 months earlier, the percentage who said “worse off” zoomed last year to 35 percent from just 13 percent as recently as 2018.

The Fed report is consistent with other recent surveys showing a pessimism that’s somewhat surprising, given the recent reduction in the (still high) inflation rate, as well as the continued strength of the job market. (The unemployment rate in April, 3.4 percent, tied for the lowest since 1969.) My Opinion colleague Paul Krugman speculated recently that negative media coverage, pessimism from economists and partisanship helped explain the divergence.

Yet inflation, albeit down from its peak, can’t be dismissed as a source of Americans’ unhappiness. The survey found that 66 percent of Americans stopped using a product or used less of it because of inflation, while 51 percent reduced their savings in response to higher prices. Among people without health insurance, 42 percent went without medical treatment because they couldn’t afford it, versus 26 percent among the insured.

A useful function of surveys such as this one is to remind us how many Americans struggle to get by even when the economy is growing. Numbers that are pointing in the right direction are still pretty bad. For example, the Fed survey asked people how they would cover an emergency expense of $400. Only 63 percent said they would pay for it using cash, savings or a credit card that they would fully pay off at the next statement. While that was better than the 50 percent who said in 2013 that they would do so, it’s still a shockingly small share. The rest said they would have to borrow, sell something or simply not pay the expense. And remember that inflation has made $400 emergency expenses more common.

I don’t want to deluge you with statistics, but I would like to finish with one interesting survey question, which is whether people would choose a different field of study if they had a chance to do things over again. People whose most recent educational program was in the humanities or arts were the most likely to say they would pick a different field, at 49 percent. Least likely to regret their choices were engineering majors. Here’s the whole chart:

In Monday’s newsletter I wrote that work requirements for social welfare programs don’t necessarily boost employment much. A reader pointed me to a 2022 study saying the same thing is true of the earned-income tax credit, which is intended to make work more rewarding for low- and moderate-income workers by reducing their taxes or increasing refunds. “Apart from the federal 1993 reform, E.I.T.C. expansions have not had any clear and significant effects on employment,” Henrik Kleven, a Princeton economist, wrote. That’s meaningful because the E.I.T.C. “dwarfs cash welfare by a factor of about 27 in terms of the number of recipients,” he wrote.
“But on principle, it is quite wrong to try founding a theory on observable magnitudes alone. In reality the very opposite happens. It is the theory which decides what we can observe.”
— Albert Einstein, as quoted by Werner Heisenberg in “Physics and Beyond: Encounters and Conversations” (1971)
question: 1. What factors contribute to the economic well-being of U.S. households, according to the Federal Reserve's survey?
close_book_answer: According to the Federal Reserve's survey, several factors contribute to the economic well-being of U.S. households. These factors include employment status, income, access to credit, and overall financial situation.

Firstly, employment status is a crucial factor that affects the economic well-being of households. A significant majority of households reported that having a job or steady income is essential for their financial stability. This highlights the importance of job creation and income stability in promoting economic well-being.

Secondly, income is another critical factor that influences the economic well-being of households. The survey found that households with higher incomes are more likely to report a high level of economic well-being compared to those with lower incomes. This suggests that income inequality is a significant challenge that needs to be addressed to ensure economic well-being for all households.

Lastly, access to credit is also an important factor that affects the economic well-being of households. The survey revealed that households with access to credit are more likely to report a high level of economic well-being compared to those without access to credit. This highlights the importance of financial literacy and access to credit in promoting economic well-being for households.

In conclusion, the Federal Reserve's survey highlights the importance of employment status, income, and access to credit in promoting the economic well-being of U.S. households. Addressing these factors will require a comprehensive approach that involves job creation, income inequality, and financial literacy.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Employment status, income, and access to credit are crucial factors that affect the economic well-being of U.S. households.
2. Having a job or steady income is essential for the financial stability of households.
3. Households with higher incomes are more likely to report a high level of economic well-being compared to those with lower incomes.
4. Access to credit is important in promoting economic well-being for households.
5. Addressing employment status, income inequality, and financial literacy is necessary to ensure economic well-being for all households.
point_form_context: 1. The Federal Reserve conducts an annual Survey of Household Economics and Decisionmaking to assess how Americans are making ends meet.
2. The 2022 report, "Economic Well-Being of U.S. Households in 2022," portrays a strong job market but unhappiness about inflation.
3. Most people feel at least "OK" about their personal situations but are down on the national economic situation.
4. The share of people who say they're doing "at least OK" financially has been stable since 2017, at around three-quarters.
5. The share who say the national economy is good or excellent has fallen sharply, to just 18 percent last year from 41 percent in 2017.

context: Every year the Federal Reserve takes a financial snapshot of America. It tells us how people are making ends meet, or not. Whether they’re (still) living with their parents, if they’ve saved money for retirement, whether they wish they had chosen a different major in college and so on.

Last year’s Survey of Household Economics and Decisionmaking, as the Fed calls it, covered 11,667 U.S. adults and was conducted online from Oct. 21 through Nov. 1. There are breakdowns by age, income, race and gender. Considering that there are no anecdotes and the writing is reserved, the Fed’s report on the survey, “Economic Well-Being of U.S. Households in 2022,” is a surprisingly human document.

The report, which was released on Monday, portrays a nation that is enjoying a strong job market but is unhappy about inflation. Most people feel at least OK about their personal situations but are down on the national economic situation. If I were sitting in the Oval Office right now, I would be concerned about the public’s fairly gloomy answers.

I’ll start with the chart that has the most political valence. It shows that the share of people who say they’re doing “at least OK” financially has been remarkably stable since 2017, at around three-quarters. The pandemic recession isn’t visible in the numbers. In contrast to that self-assessment, the share who say the national economy is good or excellent has fallen sharply, to just 18 percent last year from 41 percent in 2017.

True, some people may perceive “good or excellent” to be a tougher standard than “at least OK,” so you might expect the numbers on the national economy to be lower. What’s surprising (and bad for incumbent politicians) is that the gap in perceptions between the personal and the national has widened so much, to 55 percentage points last year from 25 percentage points in 2019.

People are comparison machines — we compare ourselves with others and with ourselves at different times — so maybe one reason for the gloomy appraisal of the national situation is that people feel things have been going in the wrong direction lately. When asked about their financial situations compared with 12 months earlier, the percentage who said “worse off” zoomed last year to 35 percent from just 13 percent as recently as 2018.

The Fed report is consistent with other recent surveys showing a pessimism that’s somewhat surprising, given the recent reduction in the (still high) inflation rate, as well as the continued strength of the job market. (The unemployment rate in April, 3.4 percent, tied for the lowest since 1969.) My Opinion colleague Paul Krugman speculated recently that negative media coverage, pessimism from economists and partisanship helped explain the divergence.

Yet inflation, albeit down from its peak, can’t be dismissed as a source of Americans’ unhappiness. The survey found that 66 percent of Americans stopped using a product or used less of it because of inflation, while 51 percent reduced their savings in response to higher prices. Among people without health insurance, 42 percent went without medical treatment because they couldn’t afford it, versus 26 percent among the insured.

A useful function of surveys such as this one is to remind us how many Americans struggle to get by even when the economy is growing. Numbers that are pointing in the right direction are still pretty bad. For example, the Fed survey asked people how they would cover an emergency expense of $400. Only 63 percent said they would pay for it using cash, savings or a credit card that they would fully pay off at the next statement. While that was better than the 50 percent who said in 2013 that they would do so, it’s still a shockingly small share. The rest said they would have to borrow, sell something or simply not pay the expense. And remember that inflation has made $400 emergency expenses more common.

I don’t want to deluge you with statistics, but I would like to finish with one interesting survey question, which is whether people would choose a different field of study if they had a chance to do things over again. People whose most recent educational program was in the humanities or arts were the most likely to say they would pick a different field, at 49 percent. Least likely to regret their choices were engineering majors. Here’s the whole chart:

In Monday’s newsletter I wrote that work requirements for social welfare programs don’t necessarily boost employment much. A reader pointed me to a 2022 study saying the same thing is true of the earned-income tax credit, which is intended to make work more rewarding for low- and moderate-income workers by reducing their taxes or increasing refunds. “Apart from the federal 1993 reform, E.I.T.C. expansions have not had any clear and significant effects on employment,” Henrik Kleven, a Princeton economist, wrote. That’s meaningful because the E.I.T.C. “dwarfs cash welfare by a factor of about 27 in terms of the number of recipients,” he wrote.
“But on principle, it is quite wrong to try founding a theory on observable magnitudes alone. In reality the very opposite happens. It is the theory which decides what we can observe.”
— Albert Einstein, as quoted by Werner Heisenberg in “Physics and Beyond: Encounters and Conversations” (1971)
question: 2. How do Americans perceive their personal financial situations compared to the national economic situation?
close_book_answer: 1. Personal Financial Situation: A study conducted by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in 2019 found that Americans' perception of their personal financial situations is generally positive, with 63% of respondents indicating that they feel financially secure. This suggests that many Americans are confident in their ability to manage their personal finances and meet their financial obligations.

2. National Economic Situation: However, when it comes to the national economic situation, Americans' perceptions are more mixed. A Pew Research Center survey conducted in January 2020 found that while a majority of Americans (57%) rated the national economy as either "excellent" or "good," this was down from 70% in 2018. Additionally, the survey found that only 34% of Americans believed that the country was heading in the right direction, while 62% believed it was on the wrong track.

3. Factors Affecting Perception: There are several factors that may influence Americans' perceptions of their personal financial situations and the national economic situation. These include income levels, political beliefs, and access to information about the economy. For example, a 2019 report by the Economic Policy Institute found that median wealth was significantly lower for households headed by someone without a college degree, while households headed by someone with a graduate degree had a median wealth of $1.1 million. Additionally, political beliefs may play a role, as a 2020 survey by The Associated Press-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research found that 84% of Democrats believed the country was headed in the wrong direction, compared to 47% of Republicans.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Americans generally feel financially secure, with 63% indicating they feel financially secure.
2. Americans' perception of the national economic situation is mixed, with 57% rating it as either excellent or good, down from 70% in 2018.
3. Only 34% of Americans believe the country is heading in the right direction, while 62% believe it is on the wrong track.
4. Factors affecting perception include income levels, political beliefs, and access to information about the economy.
5. Median wealth is significantly lower for households headed by someone without a college degree, while households headed by someone with a graduate degree have a median wealth of $1.1 million.

5. The share who say the national economy is good or excellent has fallen sharply, to just 18 percent last year from 41 percent in 2017.

question: 3. What role does inflation play in Americans' economic well-being, and how has it affected their spending habits?
close_book_answer: Inflation refers to the sustained increase in the general price level of goods and services in an economy over time, resulting in a decrease in the purchasing power of money. In the United States, inflation has played a significant role in shaping Americans' economic well-being and has had a profound impact on their spending habits.

Firstly, inflation has affected Americans' spending habits by reducing the purchasing power of their income. As prices rise, the same amount of money can buy fewer goods and services, leading to a decrease in the standard of living for many Americans. This can lead to a reduction in discretionary spending, such as on luxury items or entertainment, as people prioritize essential expenses.

Secondly, inflation can create uncertainty and anxiety among Americans about their economic future. Rising prices can make it difficult to plan for the long-term, such as saving for retirement or investing in property. This uncertainty can lead to a decrease in consumer confidence and spending, which can have a negative impact on the broader economy.

Finally, inflation can also affect Americans' spending habits by influencing their financial decisions. As prices rise, people may choose to save more and spend less in order to maintain their standard of living. This can lead to an increase in savings rates and a decrease in consumer debt, which can be beneficial in the long-term but may have short-term negative effects on economic growth.

In conclusion, inflation has a significant impact on Americans' economic well-being and spending habits. It reduces the purchasing power of money, creates uncertainty and anxiety, and influences financial decisions. While inflation may have short-term negative effects on economic growth, it is essential for maintaining a healthy economy in the long-term.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Inflation reduces the purchasing power of money in the US economy.
2. Inflation affects Americans' spending habits by reducing discretionary spending.
3. Inflation creates uncertainty and anxiety about the economic future.
4. Inflation influences financial decisions, leading to an increase in savings rates and a decrease in consumer debt.
5. Inflation has both short-term and long-term impacts on economic growth.

question: 4. What are some of the challenges that low-income Americans face when it comes to emergency expenses, and how does this impact their financial stability?
close_book_answer: 1. One of the primary challenges that low-income Americans face when it comes to emergency expenses is the lack of financial cushion. Many low-income individuals and families do not have enough savings to cover unexpected expenses such as medical bills, car repairs, or job loss. This can lead to a cycle of debt and financial instability, as they may have to resort to high-interest loans or credit cards to cover their expenses.

2. Another challenge is the lack of access to affordable financial services. Low-income individuals may not have access to traditional banking services, such as checking and savings accounts, which can make it difficult to save for emergencies or access credit. This can lead to relying on predatory lenders or payday loans, which often have high interest rates and fees that can further exacerbate their financial struggles.

3. Additionally, low-income Americans may face challenges in finding and maintaining stable employment, which can make it difficult to save for emergencies. Unstable employment can lead to income volatility, which can make it difficult to predict and plan for unexpected expenses. This can also lead to a lack of access to benefits such as paid time off or disability insurance, which can further exacerbate the financial impact of an emergency.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Lack of financial cushion among low-income individuals and families
2. Lack of access to affordable financial services
3. Challenges in finding and maintaining stable employment
4. Income volatility leading to difficulty in predicting and planning for unexpected expenses
5. Lack of access to benefits such as paid time off or disability insurance

question: 5. How do different fields of study impact an individual's likelihood of regretting their educational choice, and what factors contribute to this decision?
close_book_answer: Field of study can impact an individual's likelihood of regretting their educational choice, as different fields offer varying levels of career prospects, income potential, and job satisfaction. For instance, a study by the National Association of Colleges and Employers found that graduates in the fields of engineering, computer science, and business had higher starting salaries compared to those in the humanities and social sciences. This disparity in income potential may contribute to feelings of regret among individuals who invested in an education that did not lead to high-paying jobs.

Moreover, the demand for certain fields of study can change over time, leading to an oversupply of graduates and reduced job prospects. For example, the rise of automation and artificial intelligence has led to a decline in demand for certain jobs, such as data entry clerks and manufacturing workers. Graduates in these fields may feel regret if they invested in an education that is no longer in demand in the job market.

Finally, individual factors such as personality traits, values, and interests can also contribute to feelings of regret. For instance, an individual who values creativity and self-expression may regret choosing a field of study that does not allow for these pursuits. Similarly, a person who is highly motivated by financial success may regret investing in an education that does not lead to high earning potential.

In conclusion, different fields of study, changes in job market demand, and individual factors can all contribute to an individual's likelihood of regretting their educational choice. To minimize the risk of regret, individuals should carefully consider their interests, values, and career goals when choosing a field of study, and stay informed about the job market demand for their chosen field.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Field of study impacts likelihood of regretting educational choice.
2. Different fields offer varying levels of career prospects, income potential, and job satisfaction.
3. Graduates in engineering, computer science, and business have higher starting salaries compared to those in humanities and social sciences.
4. Disparity in income potential may contribute to feelings of regret among individuals who invested in an education that did not lead to high-paying jobs.
5. Demand for certain fields of study can change over time, leading to reduced job prospects.

context: In an interview last month, Justice Samuel Alito complained about excessive criticism of the Supreme Court. To him, this criticism has not identified discrete problems to be solved but rather represent bad-faith efforts by critics to do nothing more than give the public a “reason to question our legitimacy.”

The not-so-subtle implication of what has become a regular talking point for conservatives is that the court isn’t — and shouldn’t be — responsive to public criticism. And if that’s true, it must follow that public criticism doesn’t serve a legitimate purpose, especially if it is unlikely to spur meaningful reform from Congress.

Yet this attempt to delegitimize public criticism fails at its inception. Even if reform from Congress is not imminent, we ought not drop the focus on another potential vehicle for reforms: the court itself.

There are both historical and recent examples of how the court, in response to mounting public pressure and criticism, has changed its ways, examples that underscore the value and opportunities provided by continued public pushback today.

Perhaps the most famous example of the court’s responding to public criticism came in 1937. After the 1936 election, in which President Franklin Roosevelt ran as much against the court — which was blocking economic measures meant to respond to the dire conditions of the Depression — as against Gov. Alf Landon of Kansas, Justice Owen Roberts made the switch in time that saved nine, a shift that historians debate was due to Roosevelt’s proposal to add six seats to the court or, more generally, in response to the broader atmospherics of the president’s re-election. Either way, the court’s shift was precipitated by substantial public backlash against its recent behavior, and it opened the door to an era of greater judicial deference to economic regulation and greater judicial protection of civil rights.

To similar effect (albeit in a different direction), the Supreme Court of the mid-1970s responded to public criticism on the issue of the death penalty. When the justices effectively imposed a nationwide moratorium on capital punishment in 1972, the political backlash was extraordinary — at both the state and the federal level. In exchange for adopting a series of procedures designed to make imposition of the death penalty less arbitrary (at least in appearance), dozens of states and Congress aggressively pushed the court to reauthorize capital punishment. On July 2, 1976, the court acquiesced.

In the past 18 months, we’ve seen a similar — if subtler — shift in the court’s behavior that again closely correlates with public criticism and pushback. In this case, it has been related to how the justices issue unsigned and (usually) unexplained orders concerning applications for emergency relief, on what Will Baude, a University of Chicago law professor, first called “the shadow docket.”

Starting in 2017, there was a great shift in how the conservative majority used unsigned, unexplained orders, especially in the context of applications for emergency relief (to freeze or unfreeze lower-court rulings while a case works its way through the courts). Far more than ever before, the justices started using these orders in ways that had nationwide implications — allowing, for example, President Donald Trump to carry out a series of immigration policies that lower courts had struck down (and no court would ever uphold) and blocking a series of Covid mitigation measures in blue states on novel religious liberty grounds.

By contrast, the court showed nowhere near the same appetite to intervene to protect President Biden’s policies or to block controversial laws in red states — like Texas’ six-week abortion ban, which the court, in September 2021, allowed to go into effect, nearly 10 months before it overruled Roe v. Wade. As Justice Elena Kagan charged in her short dissent on the court’s refusal to intervene in the Texas case, the conservative majority’s behavior on the shadow docket had become increasingly “unreasoned, inconsistent and impossible to defend.”

But then something strange happened: In a little-noticed October 2021 ruling refusing to block Maine’s Covid vaccine mandate for health care workers, Justice Amy Coney Barrett wrote a cryptic concurrence (which Justice Brett Kavanaugh joined) suggesting that just because an applicant had made a case for emergency relief from the court didn’t mean the justices had to intervene. Rather, the court should use its discretion, she argued, much as it does in deciding the cases to which it will give full consideration. She didn’t say what would guide that discretion, but her brief concurrence was a turning point. To underscore that, in spring of 2022 in an emergency relief case involving environmental regulation, Chief Justice John Roberts strikingly joined a dissent by Justice Kagan, joined by Justices Stephen Breyer and Sonia Sotomayor, emphasizing concerns about the procedural shortcuts the other conservative justices had been taking.
Since then, the court has intervened far less often and in ways that have looked far less partisan even when it has granted emergency relief.

Consider the court’s decision last month to preserve nationwide access to the abortion drug mifepristone — a ruling from which only Justices Clarence Thomas and Alito publicly dissented. What changed some of the conservative justices’ minds? We’ll never know for sure, but the biggest thing that happened between the rulings in the Texas abortion case on Sept. 1, 2021, and in the Maine vaccine case on Oct. 29, 2021, was the tremendous public reaction to the earlier one. The Texas ruling brought the shadow docket into the mainstream — and the mainstream media, as an article published by The Chicago Policy Review noted. The consequences of the court’s shadow docket behavior became highly visible for nonexperts to see. And once the shadow docket went mainstream, public backlash followed.

We will all disagree as to whether public criticism of the court in specific contexts is fair. But what can’t be denied is that public pressure on the court has been, both historically and recently, a meaningful check on the institution’s excesses — and an essential means by which the public is able to hold unelected and otherwise unaccountable judges and justices to account.

In the case of the shadow docket, it has led the court to tamp down its aggressiveness and try to provide more explanations for its less justified interventions. In the hotly debated case of ethics reform going on now, all nine justices have already publicly committed to following at least broad ethical norms. The court can go further, and it can (and should) adopt formal internal mechanisms to enforce whatever rules the justices agree to bind themselves to — much in the way that internal inspectors general hold the executive and legislative branches to account.

The point is not that any one set of reforms is a magic bullet. Rather, it is that a court whose legitimacy depends at least to some degree on public support is not, should not be and never has been immune to criticism and pressure from the same public.

question: 2. How does Justice Samuel Alito view public criticism of the Supreme Court?
close_book_answer: In a 2018 speech, Justice Samuel Alito expressed his concerns about public criticism of the Supreme Court. He stated that such criticism can erode public confidence in the judiciary and undermine the Court's legitimacy. Alito argued that the Court's decisions should be respected, even if people disagree with them, in order to maintain the integrity of the judicial system.

However, Alito also acknowledged that public criticism is a fundamental part of the democratic process and that the Court should be open to constructive criticism. He emphasized the importance of educating the public about the Court's role and how it operates, in order to promote greater understanding and engagement with the judicial system.

Overall, Alito's view on public criticism of the Supreme Court is that it should be limited, but not silenced entirely. He believes that the Court should be held accountable for its decisions, but that criticism should be respectful and focused on promoting a better understanding of the judicial process.

4. Alito acknowledged that public criticism is a fundamental part of the democratic process and that the Court should be open to constructive criticism.

question: 3. What is the historical and recent examples of the court responding to public criticism?
close_book_answer: The court has a long history of responding to public criticism, as it is an important part of maintaining public trust and confidence in the judicial system. In recent times, there have been several examples of courts responding to public criticism.

One example is the response of the U.S. Supreme Court to public criticism over its Citizens United decision, which allowed corporations and unions to spend unlimited amounts of money on political advertising. In response to criticism, the Court held a rare public hearing on its rules governing campaign finance, and subsequently issued new rules aimed at increasing transparency and accountability.

Another example is the response of the U.K. Supreme Court to public criticism over its decision in the Brexit case. The court was criticized for its decision to hear the case, which was seen by some as an attempt to delay the U.K.'s exit from the European Union. In response, the court issued a statement defending its decision and explaining its role in upholding the rule of law.

Finally, the South African Constitutional Court has also responded to public criticism over its decisions. For example, in response to criticism over its decision to legalize same-sex marriage, the court held a public hearing to explain its decision and address concerns raised by religious groups.
Overall, these examples demonstrate the court's willingness to respond to public criticism and engage with the public to maintain public trust and confidence in the judicial system.

2. The U.S. Supreme Court responded to criticism over its Citizens United decision by holding a rare public hearing on its rules governing campaign finance and issuing new rules aimed at increasing transparency and accountability.
3. The U.K. Supreme Court responded to criticism over its decision in the Brexit case by issuing a statement defending its decision and explaining its role in upholding the rule of law.

4. The South African Constitutional Court responded to criticism over its decision to legalize same-sex marriage by holding a public hearing to explain its decision and address concerns raised by religious groups.
5. These examples demonstrate the court's willingness to engage with the public to maintain public trust and confidence in the judicial system.

question: 4. How did the Supreme Court of the mid-1970s respond to public criticism on the issue of the death penalty?
close_book_answer: The Supreme Court of the mid-1970s faced significant public criticism regarding the constitutionality of the death penalty. In response, the Court issued several rulings that attempted to address these concerns.

Firstly, in the case of Gregg v. Georgia (1976), the Court upheld the constitutionality of the death penalty, but imposed restrictions on its application. The Court ruled that the death penalty could be imposed if the state had a "rational" basis for believing that it would be imposed in a consistent and fair manner. This decision was seen as an attempt to address concerns that the death penalty was being applied in a racially biased manner.

Secondly, in the case of Furman v. Georgia (1972), the Court had struck down all state death penalty statutes as unconstitutional, citing their arbitrariness and lack of consistency. In response to public criticism, the Court attempted to address these concerns by imposing restrictions on the death penalty in Gregg v. Georgia.

Finally, the Court also recognized the importance of the issue of capital punishment and its impact on public opinion. In the case of Gregg v. Georgia, the Court acknowledged that the death penalty was a "political issue" and that the Court's ruling would be subject to public criticism. This recognition of the political nature of the death penalty highlights the Court's awareness of the public's concerns regarding the issue.

In conclusion, the Supreme Court of the mid-1970s responded to public criticism on the issue of the death penalty by issuing rulings that attempted to address concerns regarding its constitutionality and application. The Court's decisions in Gregg v. Georgia and Furman v. Georgia reflect the Court's efforts to balance the need for capital punishment with concerns regarding its fairness and consistency.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. The Supreme Court faced public criticism regarding the constitutionality of the death penalty in the mid-1970s.
2. The Court issued rulings in Gregg v. Georgia and Furman v. Georgia to address concerns regarding the death penalty's constitutionality and application.
3. Gregg v. Georgia upheld the constitutionality of the death penalty but imposed restrictions on its application.
4. Furman v. Georgia struck down all state death penalty statutes as unconstitutional due to arbitrariness and lack of consistency.
5. The Court recognized the political nature of the death penalty and acknowledged that its ruling would be subject to public criticism.

As Justice Elena Kagan charged in her short dissent on the court’s refusal to intervene in the Texas case, the conservative majority’s behavior on the shadow docket had become increasingly “unreasoned, inconsistent and impossible to defend.”

But then something strange happened: In a little-noticed October 2021 ruling refusing to block Maine’s Covid vaccine mandate for health care workers, Justice Amy Coney Barrett wrote a cryptic concurrence (which Justice Brett Kavanaugh joined) suggesting that just because an applicant had made a case for emergency relief from the court didn’t mean the justices had to intervene. Rather, the court should use its discretion, she argued, much as it does in deciding the cases to which it will give full consideration. She didn’t say what would guide that discretion, but her brief concurrence was a turning point. To underscore that, in spring of 2022 in an emergency relief case involving environmental regulation, Chief Justice John Roberts strikingly joined a dissent by Justice Kagan, joined by Justices Stephen Breyer and Sonia Sotomayor, emphasizing concerns about the procedural shortcuts the other conservative justices had been taking.
Since then, the court has intervened far less often and in ways that have looked far less partisan even when it has granted emergency relief.

Consider the court’s decision last month to preserve nationwide access to the abortion drug mifepristone — a ruling from which only Justices Clarence Thomas and Alito publicly dissented. What changed some of the conservative justices’ minds? We’ll never know for sure, but the biggest thing that happened between the rulings in the Texas abortion case on Sept. 1, 2021, and in the Maine vaccine case on Oct. 29, 2021, was the tremendous public reaction to the earlier one. The Texas ruling brought the shadow docket into the mainstream — and the mainstream media, as an article published by The Chicago Policy Review noted. The consequences of the court’s shadow docket behavior became highly visible for nonexperts to see. And once the shadow docket went mainstream, public backlash followed.

We will all disagree as to whether public criticism of the court in specific contexts is fair. But what can’t be denied is that public pressure on the court has been, both historically and recently, a meaningful check on the institution’s excesses — and an essential means by which the public is able to hold unelected and otherwise unaccountable judges and justices to account.

In the case of the shadow docket, it has led the court to tamp down its aggressiveness and try to provide more explanations for its less justified interventions. In the hotly debated case of ethics reform going on now, all nine justices have already publicly committed to following at least broad ethical norms. The court can go further, and it can (and should) adopt formal internal mechanisms to enforce whatever rules the justices agree to bind themselves to — much in the way that internal inspectors general hold the executive and legislative branches to account.

The point is not that any one set of reforms is a magic bullet. Rather, it is that a court whose legitimacy depends at least to some degree on public support is not, should not be and never has been immune to criticism and pressure from the same public.

4. As a result, there has been a growing demand for greater transparency and accountability in the judicial system, as well as a renewed focus on ensuring that the judiciary remains an independent and impartial branch of government that is capable of protecting the rights and liberties of all individuals, regardless of their political beliefs or social status.

5. It is crucial that the judiciary takes steps to address these concerns and restore public trust in the judicial system, in order to ensure that the rule of law remains a cornerstone of American democracy.

context: ADIYAMAN, Turkey — Adiyaman is a southern province of Turkey that a lot of people miss on a map. Too small, too poor, too pious. Too Kurdish, yet not Kurdish enough. Its neighboring provinces carry the weight of history; Adiyaman is mostly known for its loose tobacco.
In the 2014 presidential election, Recep Tayyip Erdogan won 69 percent of the vote in Adiyaman. In 2018, he won 67 percent there.

The earthquakes that struck on Feb. 6 left more than 50,000 people in Turkey and Syria dead. More than 6,000 died in Adiyaman alone, where more than 1,200 buildings collapsed and thousands more were heavily damaged. In those first essential hours, the state was nowhere to be seen. Victims lay under the rubble waiting for rescue teams for days.

That failure was supposed to jolt places like Adiyaman out of their long alliance with Mr. Erdogan. Heading into the election on Sunday, the opposition, led by Kemal Kilicdaroglu and the Republican People’s Party, the C.H.P., expected a wave of protest votes.

That election was one of the closest of Mr. Erdogan’s career. Neither party managed to claim an outright majority in the first round, and a runoff is planned for May 28. If Mr. Erdogan is confident that he’ll succeed in the second round, it might be because of places like Adiyaman, where he won 66 percent of the vote.

For some voters in Ankara and Istanbul, it seemed as if people in the southern provinces blindly voted for a president and a party that abandoned them when their need was dire. The truth is more complicated.

I spent a week in Adiyaman following the work of Oy ve Otesi (Vote and Beyond), a group that monitors elections, and talking to survivors of the earthquakes about this election. People in Adiyaman are getting by again, but things are fragile. Many lost their jobs and Turkey’s hyperinflation has hit the region hard. But for now the government is paying attention. Families that were made homeless by the earthquakes are starting to settle into temporary housing. In one camp, container houses sent from Qatar overheat in the sun, but the road is freshly paved. A huge poster of Mr. Erdogan nearby promised free natural gas for a year. Mr. Kilicdaroglu pledged free housing for earthquake victims on another poster, but that one was a three-and-a-half-mile drive away.

Zeynep, a mother of four children whose husband was in the army, told me that supplies from the disaster relief ministry and her husband’s recent raise in wages, courtesy of Mr. Erdogan’s government, were what allowed her to feed her family. Zeynep asked me not to use her full name for her husband’s sake. She favored Mr. Kilicdaroglu and the pro-Kurdish Peoples’ Democratic Party, the H.D.P. Her husband is in the special operation forces, fighting Kurdish insurgents. She wasn’t going to vote in the first round. Maybe, she said, she’d vote in the second.

Sevgi, also a housewife, planned to vote but kept changing her mind. She didn’t like Mr. Erdogan, at least not anymore, but she was afraid of what her family would do if they found out she voted for the C.H.P.: the party of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk and secularism; the party that once supported a ban against the head scarf in public institutions. Who knows, her family might say, what the C.H.P. would do next.

On the other side of town, near the local university, Ekrem Abaci, a muhtar — a sort of neighborhood representative — ordered people around in his office. Men unloaded water jugs from the trucks that kept arriving. The disaster response ministry was sending daily deliveries of water that the muhtar could distribute among his constituency. He and the men around him all told me the same thing: Our government took care of us. It may have come late, but any country would have been the same in such a disaster. The government is not to blame.

“Vote for Papa Tayyip tomorrow,” the muhtar called out to Hakan, a graduate student with a broken arm who had come in to collect some papers. Hakan was quiet for a moment, then he told me I could restart the voice recorder that I’d paused when he came in. He said that he’d voted his whole life for Mr. Erdogan and his party, but he wouldn’t this time. He’d vote against the nepotism that has left so many graduates like him unemployed, and the bureaucratic rot that means he gets fined when he shouldn’t and can’t get access to benefits he’s entitled to. Then he left.

It’s not that nothing in Adiyaman and neighboring provinces has changed: Many of the areas hit hardest by the earthquakes, which have historically supported Mr. Erdogan, shifted away from him in the first round. But when the sidewalk still crunches with leftover debris; when neighborhoods are still a mix of empty lots, where buildings once stood, and scattered tents; and when life is still a question of today, not tomorrow, a vote for change can feel like a big gamble.
question: 1. What factors contribute to Adiyaman being overlooked in maps and politics?

2. Lack of significant historical or cultural landmarks: The city may not have the same level of historical or cultural significance as other regions in Turkey, which could lead to it being overlooked in maps and politics.
3. Limited media coverage: The lack of media coverage of Adiyaman compared to other regions in Turkey may contribute to its being overshadowed and overlooked in maps and politics.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Geographic isolation contributes to Adiyaman's relative obscurity compared to other regions.
2. Lack of historical or cultural landmarks may lead to Adiyaman being overlooked in maps and politics.
3. Limited media coverage of Adiyaman compared to other regions in Turkey may contribute to its being overshadowed and overlooked.

2. In the 2014 and 2018 presidential elections, Recep Tayyip Erdogan won 69 and 67 percent of the vote in Adiyaman, respectively.
3. The earthquakes that struck in February 2018 left more than 50,000 people dead, with more than 1,200 buildings collapsing and thousands more being heavily damaged in Adiyaman.
4. The government's response to the earthquake was slow, and many victims waited for rescue teams for days.

5. Despite the earthquake and hyperinflation, the government's attention and aid has allowed families to start settling into temporary housing, and some are still deciding who to vote for in the upcoming election.

question: 2. How has the earthquake disaster affected the political landscape in Adiyaman?
close_book_answer: 1. The earthquake disaster in Adiyaman has had a significant impact on the political landscape of the region. The disaster has brought to light the inadequacies of the current political infrastructure in terms of disaster response and management. The lack of preparedness and the slow response from the government and local authorities have resulted in a loss of public trust and confidence in the political establishment.

2. The earthquake disaster has also highlighted the need for better coordination and communication between different levels of government. The disaster has exposed the weaknesses in the existing political system, which has resulted in a lack of coordination and communication between local and national authorities. This has led to a lack of effective response and a failure to provide adequate support to the affected communities.

3. Furthermore, the earthquake disaster has provided an opportunity for political parties to re-evaluate their priorities and policies in relation to disaster management. Political parties may need to reassess their priorities and policies in relation to disaster management, and may need to make changes to ensure that they are better equipped to respond to future disasters. The disaster has also provided an opportunity for new political parties to emerge, which may offer a new perspective on disaster management and the political response to disasters.

question: 3. What role does the government's response to the earthquake play in the upcoming election?
close_book_answer: The government's response to the earthquake can play a significant role in the upcoming election. The way the government handles the disaster and its aftermath can impact public opinion and voter behavior. If the government's response is seen as effective and efficient, it can boost their popularity and increase their chances of winning the election. On the other hand, if the response is perceived as inadequate or incompetent, it can lead to public outrage and backlash, potentially resulting in the loss of votes and seats in the election.

Moreover, the government's response to the earthquake can also highlight their priorities and values. For instance, if the government allocates significant resources to disaster relief and rebuilding, it can signal their commitment to the welfare of the people and their willingness to invest in the future of the country. Conversely, if the government is perceived as more focused on political gains or personal interests, it can damage their reputation and undermine public trust.

In addition, the government's response to the earthquake can also shape the political discourse in the lead-up to the election. The way the government communicates its actions and policies can influence public opinion and shape the narrative of the election. For example, if the government frames their response as a demonstration of leadership and resilience, it can resonate with voters and reinforce their image as competent and capable leaders. On the other hand, if the opposition party highlights the government's failures and inadequacies in responding to the earthquake, it can undermine their credibility and create an opportunity for the opposition to gain traction.

In conclusion, the government's response to the earthquake can have a significant impact on the upcoming election. The way the government handles the disaster and its aftermath can shape public opinion, voter behavior, and the political discourse. It is therefore crucial for the government to prioritize the needs of the people and communicate their actions and policies effectively to maintain public trust and support.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Government's response to earthquake can impact public opinion and voter behavior.
2. Effective and efficient response can boost government's popularity and increase their chances of winning the election.
3. Inadequate or incompetent response can lead to public outrage and backlash, potentially resulting in the loss of votes and seats in the election.
4. Government's response can highlight their priorities and values.
5. The way the government communicates their actions and policies can influence public opinion and shape the narrative of the election.

5. Despite the earthquake and hyperinflation, the government's attention and aid has allowed families to start settling into temporary housing, and some are still deciding who to vote for in the upcoming election.

context: ADIYAMAN, Turkey — Adiyaman is a southern province of Turkey that a lot of people miss on a map. Too small, too poor, too pious. Too Kurdish, yet not Kurdish enough. Its neighboring provinces carry the weight of history; Adiyaman is mostly known for its loose tobacco.
In the 2014 presidential election, Recep Tayyip Erdogan won 69 percent of the vote in Adiyaman. In 2018, he won 67 percent there.

The earthquakes that struck on Feb. 6 left more than 50,000 people in Turkey and Syria dead. More than 6,000 died in Adiyaman alone, where more than 1,200 buildings collapsed and thousands more were heavily damaged. In those first essential hours, the state was nowhere to be seen. Victims lay under the rubble waiting for rescue teams for days.

That failure was supposed to jolt places like Adiyaman out of their long alliance with Mr. Erdogan. Heading into the election on Sunday, the opposition, led by Kemal Kilicdaroglu and the Republican People’s Party, the C.H.P., expected a wave of protest votes.

That election was one of the closest of Mr. Erdogan’s career. Neither party managed to claim an outright majority in the first round, and a runoff is planned for May 28. If Mr. Erdogan is confident that he’ll succeed in the second round, it might be because of places like Adiyaman, where he won 66 percent of the vote.

For some voters in Ankara and Istanbul, it seemed as if people in the southern provinces blindly voted for a president and a party that abandoned them when their need was dire. The truth is more complicated.

I spent a week in Adiyaman following the work of Oy ve Otesi (Vote and Beyond), a group that monitors elections, and talking to survivors of the earthquakes about this election. People in Adiyaman are getting by again, but things are fragile. Many lost their jobs and Turkey’s hyperinflation has hit the region hard. But for now the government is paying attention. Families that were made homeless by the earthquakes are starting to settle into temporary housing. In one camp, container houses sent from Qatar overheat in the sun, but the road is freshly paved. A huge poster of Mr. Erdogan nearby promised free natural gas for a year. Mr. Kilicdaroglu pledged free housing for earthquake victims on another poster, but that one was a three-and-a-half-mile drive away.

Zeynep, a mother of four children whose husband was in the army, told me that supplies from the disaster relief ministry and her husband’s recent raise in wages, courtesy of Mr. Erdogan’s government, were what allowed her to feed her family. Zeynep asked me not to use her full name for her husband’s sake. She favored Mr. Kilicdaroglu and the pro-Kurdish Peoples’ Democratic Party, the H.D.P. Her husband is in the special operation forces, fighting Kurdish insurgents. She wasn’t going to vote in the first round. Maybe, she said, she’d vote in the second.

Sevgi, also a housewife, planned to vote but kept changing her mind. She didn’t like Mr. Erdogan, at least not anymore, but she was afraid of what her family would do if they found out she voted for the C.H.P.: the party of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk and secularism; the party that once supported a ban against the head scarf in public institutions. Who knows, her family might say, what the C.H.P. would do next.

On the other side of town, near the local university, Ekrem Abaci, a muhtar — a sort of neighborhood representative — ordered people around in his office. Men unloaded water jugs from the trucks that kept arriving. The disaster response ministry was sending daily deliveries of water that the muhtar could distribute among his constituency. He and the men around him all told me the same thing: Our government took care of us. It may have come late, but any country would have been the same in such a disaster. The government is not to blame.

“Vote for Papa Tayyip tomorrow,” the muhtar called out to Hakan, a graduate student with a broken arm who had come in to collect some papers. Hakan was quiet for a moment, then he told me I could restart the voice recorder that I’d paused when he came in. He said that he’d voted his whole life for Mr. Erdogan and his party, but he wouldn’t this time. He’d vote against the nepotism that has left so many graduates like him unemployed, and the bureaucratic rot that means he gets fined when he shouldn’t and can’t get access to benefits he’s entitled to. Then he left.

It’s not that nothing in Adiyaman and neighboring provinces has changed: Many of the areas hit hardest by the earthquakes, which have historically supported Mr. Erdogan, shifted away from him in the first round. But when the sidewalk still crunches with leftover debris; when neighborhoods are still a mix of empty lots, where buildings once stood, and scattered tents; and when life is still a question of today, not tomorrow, a vote for change can feel like a big gamble.
question: 5. What are the main concerns of voters in Adiyaman, and how do they weigh the pros and cons of voting for the ruling party or the opposition?
close_book_answer: 1. The main concerns of voters in Adiyaman are likely to revolve around local issues such as economic development, infrastructure, and public services. They may also be influenced by national issues such as political stability, security, and social welfare.

2. When weighing the pros and cons of voting for the ruling party or the opposition, voters in Adiyaman may consider factors such as the party's track record on addressing local concerns, their perceived competence and trustworthiness, and the potential impact of their policies on the local economy and community.

3. Additionally, voters in Adiyaman may also be influenced by external factors such as media coverage, political rhetoric, and the opinions of their peers and community leaders. Ultimately, their decision will depend on their individual values, priorities, and perceptions of the parties and candidates.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Local issues such as economic development, infrastructure, and public services are likely to be the main concerns of voters in Adiyaman.

2. Voters may consider the party's track record on addressing local concerns, their perceived competence and trustworthiness, and the potential impact of their policies on the local economy and community when weighing the pros and cons of voting for the ruling party or the opposition.
3. External factors such as media coverage, political rhetoric, and the opinions of their peers and community leaders may also influence voters in Adiyaman.
4. Voter decision will depend on their individual values, priorities, and perceptions of the parties and candidates.
5. Voters in Adiyaman may also be influenced by national issues such as political stability, security, and social welfare.
point_form_context: 1. Adiyaman is a southern province of Turkey that is known for its loose tobacco and is mostly Kurdish.
2. In the 2014 and 2018 presidential elections, Recep Tayyip Erdogan won 69 and 67 percent of the vote in Adiyaman, respectively.
3. The earthquakes that struck in February 2018 left more than 50,000 people dead, with more than 1,200 buildings collapsing and thousands more being heavily damaged in Adiyaman.
4. The government's response to the earthquake was slow, and many victims waited for rescue teams for days.

5. Despite the earthquake and hyperinflation, the government's attention and aid has allowed families to start settling into temporary housing, and some are still deciding who to vote for in the upcoming election.

context: Almost a year has passed since the Bureau of Economic Analysis announced that the U.S. economy had contracted for two quarters in a row. Some people believe, wrongly, that two quarters of falling G.D.P. is the official definition of a recession. Economic negativity ran rampant, especially but not only on the political right.

The interesting question now is why, at least according to some surveys, the public remains very negative on the economy — as negative as it has been in the past amid severe economic downturns — even though those recession calls were clearly a false alarm, and the economy is actually looking remarkably strong. Or maybe the question should be why people say that they’re very negative on the economy.

This is a touchy subject, albeit one I’ve commented on before. You don’t want to say that Americans are stupid; you certainly don’t want to sound like that John McCain adviser who insisted that America was a “nation of whiners” who were experiencing only a “mental recession.”

On the other hand, there are now huge gaps between what people say about the economy and both what the data says and what they say about their own experience. And we have some new information on what lies behind these gaps.

First, about that much-hyped “Biden recession.” The actual definition of a recession involves several economic indicators, and aside from those G.D.P. numbers, nothing that has happened to the economy looks remotely like a recession.

Since December 2021 the U.S. economy has added almost six million jobs while the unemployment rate has fallen from 3.9 percent to 3.4 percent, a level not seen since the 1960s. And no, unemployment isn’t low because Americans have dropped out of the labor force: The percentage of adults either working or looking for a job has declined, but that’s almost entirely a result of an aging population, and labor force participation is right back in line with prepandemic projections.
And these are good jobs, according to workers themselves. According to the Conference Board, which has been surveying job satisfaction since 1987, “U.S. workers have never been more content.”

To be sure, the return of serious inflation after decades of quiescence rattled everyone, and not just because it reduced real incomes. (Real wages fell during Ronald Reagan’s second term, but people felt pretty good about the economy anyway.) One benefit of low inflation is that it gives people one less thing to worry about; according to the American Psychological Association, inflation was a major source of stress during 2022.

But inflation, while still elevated, has come way down. The inflation rate over the past six months was 3.3 percent, compared with 9.6 percent last June. The price of gasoline, a major political talking point last year, is now more or less normal compared with average earnings.
And people have noticed. In October, 20 percent of Americans named inflation as the most important problem facing the nation; that’s now down to 9 percent.

So what’s going on? The general rule seems to be that Americans are feeling good about their personal situation but believe that bad things are happening to other people. A Federal Reserve study found that in late 2021 a record-high percentage of Americans were positive about their own finances while a record low were positive about the economy. We don’t have results for 2022 yet, but my guess is that they’ll look similar.

Partisanship surely explains much of this divergence. A newly published study shows that who holds the White House has huge effects on views of the economy; this is true for supporters of both parties, although the effect appears to be about twice as strong for Republicans. The study also finds, however, that these changes in reported views don’t appear to have any effect on actual spending — that they reflect “cheerleading,” as opposed to “actual expectations.”

Beyond that, there’s good reason to believe that media reports about the economy have had a strongly negative bias. One thing that has gone really, really right in America lately is job creation, yet the public consistently reports having heard more negative than positive news about employment.

And let’s not let economists off the hook. As Mark Zandi of Moody’s Analytics points out, many economists have been predicting recession month after month for the past year. Sooner or later, a recession will no doubt happen, but as he says, “In my 30-plus years as a professional economist, I’ve never seen such recession pessimism,” even as the economy has remained resilient. And this pessimism has surely filtered through to the public.

So where does all this leave us? America hasn’t yet brought inflation back to prepandemic levels, and we may yet have an economic hard landing. But so far, at least, we’ve had a stunningly successful recovery from the Covid shock.

While many Americans tell surveys that things are terrible — which says something about how people respond to surveys and where they get their information — this doesn’t contradict that positive assessment.
question: 1. What factors contribute to the public's continued negative perception of the economy, despite evidence of a strong recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic?
close_book_answer: 1. One factor contributing to the public's continued negative perception of the economy is the lingering effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Even though there has been a strong recovery, many people are still struggling financially due to lost income and business closures. This has led to increased levels of personal debt and economic uncertainty, which can create a sense of pessimism about the future of the economy.

2. Another factor is the unequal distribution of the recovery's benefits. While some sectors of the economy have seen significant growth, others have not. This has led to a widening income gap and a sense of unfairness among those who have not benefited from the recovery. Additionally, the recovery may not be felt evenly across different regions, leading to a perception that the economy is not recovering for everyone.

3. Finally, the media's coverage of the economy can also contribute to a negative perception. While it is important to report on the challenges facing the economy, constant negative coverage can create a sense of hopelessness and fear among the public. This can be particularly true for those who are already struggling financially and may be more vulnerable to negative news.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. COVID-19 pandemic's lingering effects on personal debt and economic uncertainty
2. Unequal distribution of recovery's benefits, widening income gap, and unfairness
3. Media's coverage of the economy can contribute to negative perception and fear
4. Recovery may not be felt evenly across different regions
5. Challenges facing the economy reported by the media
point_form_context: 1. The US economy contracted for two quarters in a row, leading to widespread economic negativity.
2. Despite the false alarm of a recession, the economy is looking remarkably strong, with six million jobs added since December 2021 and an unemployment rate of 3.4 percent.
3. The return of serious inflation rattled everyone, but it has come way down, with the inflation rate over the past six months being 3.3 percent.
4. Americans are feeling good about their personal situation but believe that bad things are happening to other people.
5. Partisanship and media reports about the economy have had a strongly negative bias, and many economists have been predicting recession month after month for the past year.

question: 2. How do political beliefs influence individuals' perceptions of the economy, and why do some people insist on labeling any economic downturn as a "recession"?
close_book_answer: 1. Political beliefs can greatly influence an individual's perception of the economy. For example, individuals who identify as conservative tend to have a more positive outlook on the economy, while those who identify as liberal tend to have a more negative outlook. This is because conservatives tend to place more emphasis on individual responsibility and the role of the market in driving economic growth, while liberals tend to place more emphasis on government intervention and social justice.

2. One reason why some people insist on labeling any economic downturn as a "recession" is because it can elicit a negative emotional response from others. By using a word like "recession," individuals can create a sense of urgency and anxiety around economic issues, which can lead to calls for government action or other policy changes. Additionally, labeling an economic downturn as a "recession" can help to create a sense of shared experience among those who are affected, which can lead to increased solidarity and collective action.

3. However, it is important to note that not all economic downturns meet the technical definition of a recession. A recession is typically defined as a period of economic decline that lasts for at least six months and is marked by a decrease in gross domestic product (GDP) and an increase in unemployment. By labeling every economic downturn as a recession, some individuals may be engaging in hyperbole or even spreading misinformation. This can lead to confusion and a lack of trust in the accuracy of economic data and analysis.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Political beliefs influence perception of the economy.
2. Labeling an economic downturn as a "recession" can elicit a negative emotional response and lead to policy changes.
3. Not all economic downturns meet the technical definition of a recession.
4. Labeling every economic downturn as a recession can lead to confusion and a lack of trust in economic data.
5. The definition of a recession is a period of economic decline lasting at least six months with a decrease in GDP and increase in unemployment.
point_form_context: 1. The US economy contracted for two quarters in a row, leading to widespread economic negativity.
2. Despite the false alarm of a recession, the economy is looking remarkably strong, with six million jobs added since December 2021 and an unemployment rate of 3.4 percent.
3. The return of serious inflation rattled everyone, but it has come way down, with the inflation rate over the past six months being 3.3 percent.
4. Americans are feeling good about their personal situation but believe that bad things are happening to other people.
5. Partisanship and media reports about the economy have had a strongly negative bias, and many economists have been predicting recession month after month for the past year.
