context: There are a few reasons to think that President Biden might lose his bid for re-election next year, even if Donald Trump is once more — for the third straight time — the Republican nominee.

There’s the Electoral College, which could still favor the Republican Party just enough to give Trump 270 electoral votes, even if he doesn’t win a popular majority. There’s Biden’s overall standing — around 43 percent of Americans approve of his job performance — which doesn’t compare favorably with past incumbents who did win re-election. There’s the economy, which may hit a downturn between now and next November. And even if it doesn’t, Biden will still have presided over the highest inflation rate since the 1980s. Last, there’s Biden himself. The oldest person ever elected president, next year he will be — at 81 — the oldest president to ever stand for re-election. Biden’s age is a real risk that could suddenly become a liability.

If Biden has potential weaknesses, however, it is also true that he doesn’t lack for real advantages. Along with low unemployment, there’s been meaningful economic growth, and he can point to significant legislative accomplishments. The Democratic Party is behind him; he has no serious rivals for the nomination.

But Biden’s biggest advantage has to do with the opposition — the Republican Party has gotten weird. It’s not just that Republican policies are well outside the mainstream, but that the party itself has tipped over into something very strange.

I had this thought while watching a clip of Ron DeSantis speak from a lectern to an audience we can’t see. In the video, which his press team highlighted on Twitter, DeSantis decries the “woke mind virus,” which he calls “a form of cultural Marxism that tries to divide us based on identity politics.”

Now, I can follow this as a professional internet user and political observer. I know that “woke mind virus” is a term of art for the (condescending and misguided) idea that progressive views on race and gender are an outside contagion threatening the minds of young people who might otherwise reject structural explanations of racial inequality and embrace a traditional vision of the gender binary. I know that “cultural Marxism” is a right-wing buzzword meant to sound scary and imposing.

To a normal person, on the other hand, this language is borderline unintelligible. It doesn’t tell you anything; it doesn’t obviously mean anything; and it’s quite likely to be far afield of your interests and concerns.

DeSantis is a regular offender when it comes to speaking in the jargon of culture war-obsessed conservatives, but he’s not the only one. And it’s not just a problem of jargon. Republican politicians — from presidential contenders to anonymous state legislators — are monomaniacally focused on banning books, fighting “wokeness” and harassing transgender people. Some Republicans are even still denying the legitimacy of the 2020 presidential election, doubling down on the election-related conspiracies that hobbled many Republican candidates in the midterms.

Not only do Americans not care about the various Republican obsessions — in a recent Fox News poll 1 percent of respondents said “wokeness” was “the most important issue facing the country today” — but a large majority say that those obsessions have gone too far. According to Fox, 60 percent of Americans said “book banning by school boards” was a major problem. Fifty-seven percent said the same for political attacks on families with transgender children.
It is not for nothing that in Biden’s first TV ad of the 2024 campaign, he took specific aim at conservative book bans as a threat to freedom and American democracy.

And yet there’s no sign that Republicans will relent and shift focus. Just the opposite, in fact; the party is poised to lurch even farther down the road of its alienating preoccupations. On abortion, for example, Ronna McDaniel, the chairwoman of the Republican National Committee, says candidates need to address the issue “head-on” in 2024 — that they can’t be “uncomfortable” on the issue and need to say “I’m proud to be pro-life.”

But the Republican Party has veered quite far from most Americans on abortion rights, and in a contested race for the presidential nomination, a “head-on” focus will possibly mean a fight over which candidate can claim the most draconian abortion views and policy aims.

There’s more: DeSantis is in the midst of a legal battle with Disney, one of the most beloved companies on the planet, and House Republicans are threatening the global economy in order to pass a set of deeply unpopular spending cuts to widely used assistance programs.

Taken together, it’s as if the Republican Party has committed itself to being as off-putting as possible to as many Americans as possible. That doesn’t mean the party is doomed, of course. But as of this moment, it is hard to say it’s on the road to political success.

As for Joe Biden? The current state of the Republican Party only strengthens his most important political asset — his normalcy. He promised, in 2020, that he would be a normal president. And he is promising, for 2024, to continue to serve as a normal president. Normal isn’t fun and normal isn’t exciting. But normal has already won one election, and I won’t be surprised if it wins another.
question: 1. What factors could potentially hinder President Biden's re-election bid in 2024?
close_book_answer: 1. One potential factor that could hinder President Biden's re-election bid in 2024 is the performance of the economy. If the economy experiences a significant downturn or stagnation during his term, voters may be less likely to re-elect him. Additionally, if the President's policies are seen as responsible for the economic difficulties, this could also hurt his chances of re-election.

2. Another factor that could impact President Biden's re-election bid is the performance of his administration in addressing key issues such as healthcare, immigration, and climate change. If voters perceive that the President has not adequately addressed these issues or has taken actions that are perceived as inadequate or ineffective, this could lead to a loss of support and hinder his re-election chances.

3. Finally, the political climate in the United States is constantly evolving, and it is possible that a strong challenger could emerge from within the Democratic party to challenge President Biden for the nomination. If this challenger is able to effectively mobilize support and appeal to voters on key issues, they could potentially hinder President Biden's re-election bid.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Economic performance
2. Addressing key issues
3. Strong challenger within Democratic party
point_form_context: 1. President Biden may lose his re-election bid in 2024 due to various factors such as the Electoral College, his job performance, the economy, his age, and the opposition from the Republican Party.
2. Biden has potential weaknesses, but he also has advantages such as low unemployment, meaningful economic growth, significant legislative accomplishments, and the support of the Democratic Party.
3. The Republican Party has become "weird" and its policies are outside the mainstream, which may hurt its chances in the election.
4. The opposition to Biden is focused on banning books, fighting "wokeness," and harassing transgender people, which may not resonate with most Americans.
5. The Republican Party is poised to lurch even farther down the road of its alienating preoccupations, which may further distance it from most Americans.

Now, I can follow this as a professional internet user and political observer. I know that “woke mind virus” is a term of art for the (condescending and misguided) idea that progressive views on race and gender are an outside contagion threatening the minds of young people who might otherwise reject structural explanations of racial inequality and embrace a traditional vision of the gender binary. I know that “cultural Marxism” is a right-wing buzzword meant to sound scary and imposing.

To a normal person, on the other hand, this language is borderline unintelligible. It doesn’t tell you anything; it doesn’t obviously mean anything; and it’s quite likely to be far afield of your interests and concerns.

DeSantis is a regular offender when it comes to speaking in the jargon of culture war-obsessed conservatives, but he’s not the only one. And it’s not just a problem of jargon. Republican politicians — from presidential contenders to anonymous state legislators — are monomaniacally focused on banning books, fighting “wokeness” and harassing transgender people. Some Republicans are even still denying the legitimacy of the 2020 presidential election, doubling down on the election-related conspiracies that hobbled many Republican candidates in the midterms.

Not only do Americans not care about the various Republican obsessions — in a recent Fox News poll 1 percent of respondents said “wokeness” was “the most important issue facing the country today” — but a large majority say that those obsessions have gone too far. According to Fox, 60 percent of Americans said “book banning by school boards” was a major problem. Fifty-seven percent said the same for political attacks on families with transgender children.
It is not for nothing that in Biden’s first TV ad of the 2024 campaign, he took specific aim at conservative book bans as a threat to freedom and American democracy.

And yet there’s no sign that Republicans will relent and shift focus. Just the opposite, in fact; the party is poised to lurch even farther down the road of its alienating preoccupations. On abortion, for example, Ronna McDaniel, the chairwoman of the Republican National Committee, says candidates need to address the issue “head-on” in 2024 — that they can’t be “uncomfortable” on the issue and need to say “I’m proud to be pro-life.”

But the Republican Party has veered quite far from most Americans on abortion rights, and in a contested race for the presidential nomination, a “head-on” focus will possibly mean a fight over which candidate can claim the most draconian abortion views and policy aims.

There’s more: DeSantis is in the midst of a legal battle with Disney, one of the most beloved companies on the planet, and House Republicans are threatening the global economy in order to pass a set of deeply unpopular spending cuts to widely used assistance programs.

Taken together, it’s as if the Republican Party has committed itself to being as off-putting as possible to as many Americans as possible. That doesn’t mean the party is doomed, of course. But as of this moment, it is hard to say it’s on the road to political success.

As for Joe Biden? The current state of the Republican Party only strengthens his most important political asset — his normalcy. He promised, in 2020, that he would be a normal president. And he is promising, for 2024, to continue to serve as a normal president. Normal isn’t fun and normal isn’t exciting. But normal has already won one election, and I won’t be surprised if it wins another.
question: 2. How does the current state of the Republican Party affect their chances in the 2024 election?
close_book_answer: The current state of the Republican Party has a significant impact on their chances in the 2024 election.
The party has been facing internal divisions and infighting, which has resulted in a lack of unity and cohesion.
Additionally, the party has struggled to appeal to a diverse electorate, which could hurt their chances in a presidential election where demographics are becoming increasingly important.
Furthermore, the party's association with the Trump administration and its controversial policies has led to a decline in support among moderate and independent voters.
This, coupled with the Democrats' focus on issues such as healthcare, climate change, and economic inequality, could make it difficult for the Republicans to win the 2024 election..

3. The association of the party with the Trump administration and its controversial policies has led to a decline in support among moderate and independent voters.
4. The Democrats' focus on issues such as healthcare, climate change, and economic inequality could make it difficult for the Republicans to win the 2024 election.
5. The current state of the Republican Party has significant impact on their chances in the 2024 election.

context: There are a few reasons to think that President Biden might lose his bid for re-election next year, even if Donald Trump is once more — for the third straight time — the Republican nominee.

There’s the Electoral College, which could still favor the Republican Party just enough to give Trump 270 electoral votes, even if he doesn’t win a popular majority. There’s Biden’s overall standing — around 43 percent of Americans approve of his job performance — which doesn’t compare favorably with past incumbents who did win re-election. There’s the economy, which may hit a downturn between now and next November. And even if it doesn’t, Biden will still have presided over the highest inflation rate since the 1980s. Last, there’s Biden himself. The oldest person ever elected president, next year he will be — at 81 — the oldest president to ever stand for re-election. Biden’s age is a real risk that could suddenly become a liability.

If Biden has potential weaknesses, however, it is also true that he doesn’t lack for real advantages. Along with low unemployment, there’s been meaningful economic growth, and he can point to significant legislative accomplishments. The Democratic Party is behind him; he has no serious rivals for the nomination.

But Biden’s biggest advantage has to do with the opposition — the Republican Party has gotten weird. It’s not just that Republican policies are well outside the mainstream, but that the party itself has tipped over into something very strange.

question: 3. How does President Biden's age and health play a role in his re-election campaign?
close_book_answer: The issue of President Biden's age and health has been a topic of discussion in his re-election campaign. Some argue that his age and health may be a concern for his ability to serve another term, while others argue that it is not a factor in his ability to lead the country.

Claim 1: President Biden's age and health are not a concern for his ability to lead the country. Supporters argue that at 78 years old, he is still mentally sharp and physically fit to continue serving as President. They point to his extensive experience in politics and leadership roles, as well as his ability to handle the demands of the job.

Claim 2: President Biden's age and health may be a concern for his ability to serve another term. Critics argue that at his age, he may not have the physical and mental stamina to handle the demands of the job. They also raise concerns about his health, given his history of heart problems and recent health scares.

Claim 3: The issue of President Biden's age and health may be used as a political tool by his opponents in the re-election campaign. Some argue that his opponents may try to use his age and health against him, suggesting that he is too old and frail to continue serving as President. This could potentially impact his re-election chances, as some voters may be swayed by these concerns.

question: 4. What are some of the economic factors that could impact the election outcome?
close_book_answer: 1. Economic factors play a significant role in shaping the outcome of an election. The state of the economy, including factors such as unemployment rates, GDP growth, and income inequality, can greatly influence voter preferences and ultimately the election results.

2. During times of economic uncertainty or recession, voters may be more likely to support candidates who promise to address these issues and improve their economic situation. Conversely, during periods of economic growth and stability, voters may be more likely to support candidates who align with their political beliefs and values.

3. The distribution of wealth and income can also impact the election outcome. Candidates who advocate for policies that address income inequality and support lower-income voters may be more likely to gain support from these groups, potentially leading to their election.

4. Additionally, the impact of economic factors on the election outcome can vary depending on the country and its unique political and economic context. For example, in the United States, issues such as healthcare and immigration may be more salient in an election year, while in other countries, economic issues may take center stage.
5. Therefore, it is crucial for political candidates to understand and address the economic concerns of voters in order to increase their chances of winning the election.

2. Voters may be more likely to support candidates who address economic issues during times of uncertainty or recession, or those who align with their political beliefs and values during periods of growth and stability.
3. Candidates who advocate for policies addressing income inequality and supporting lower-income voters may gain support from these groups.
4. The impact of economic factors on the election outcome can vary depending on the country's unique political and economic context.
5. Political candidates must understand and address voters' economic concerns to increase their chances of winning the election.

question: 5. How does the Democratic Party's support for President Biden compare to the Republican Party's support for their candidate?
close_book_answer: The level of support for President Biden among the Democratic Party is likely to be significantly higher than the support for the Republican candidate among the Republican Party. This is because the Democratic Party generally tends to have a more cohesive and unified base of supporters, who are more likely to vote for their party's candidate in the election. Additionally, the Democratic Party has a larger base of voters who tend to be more supportive of progressive policies and issues, which are likely to align with President Biden's policies and positions.

On the other hand, the Republican Party has a more diverse base of supporters, with some who may be more conservative and others who may be more moderate. This can make it more difficult for the party to achieve a high level of support for their candidate, as some voters may be more likely to support a third-party candidate or to abstain from voting altogether. Additionally, the Republican Party has a more polarized base of voters, with some who may be more critical of President Biden's policies and positions.

Overall, while both parties have some level of support for their candidates, the Democratic Party is likely to have a more unified and cohesive base of supporters, which may result in higher levels of support for President Biden.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Democratic Party has a more cohesive and unified base of supporters than the Republican Party.
2. Democratic Party has a larger base of voters who tend to be more supportive of progressive policies and issues.
3. The Republican Party has a more diverse base of supporters, with some who may be more conservative and others who may be more moderate.
4. The Republican Party has a more polarized base of voters, with some who may be more critical of President Biden's policies and positions.
5. The Democratic Party is likely to have higher levels of support for President Biden due to their more unified and cohesive base of supporters.

context: Joe Biden has, to nobody’s surprise, formally announced that he is seeking re-election. And I, for one, am dreading the year and a half of political crystal ball gazing that lies ahead of us — a discussion to which I will have little if anything to add.

One thing I may be able to contribute to, however, is the way we talk about the Biden economy. Much political discussion, it seems to me, is informed by a sense that the economy will be a major liability for Democrats — a sense that is strongly affected by out-of-date or questionable data.

Of course, a lot can change between now and November 2024. We could have a recession, maybe as the delayed effect of monetary tightening by the Federal Reserve. We might all too easily face a financial crisis this summer when, as seems likely, Republicans refuse to raise the debt ceiling — and nobody knows how that will play out politically.
Right now, however, the economy is in better shape than I suspect most pundits or even generally well-informed readers may realize.

The basic story of the Biden economy is that America has experienced a remarkably fast and essentially complete job market recovery. This recovery was initially accompanied by distressingly high inflation; but inflation, while still high by the standards of the past few decades, has subsided substantially. The overall situation is, well, not so bad.

About jobs: Unless you’ve been getting your news from Tucker Carlson or Truth Social, you’re probably aware that the unemployment rate is hovering near historic lows. However, I keep hearing assertions that this number is misleading, because millions of Americans have dropped out of the labor force — which was true a year ago.

But it’s not true anymore. There are multiple ways to make this point, but one way is to compare where we are now with projections made just before Covid struck. In January 2020 the Congressional Budget Office projected that by the first quarter of 2023 nonfarm employment would be 154.8 million; the actual number for March was 155.6 million. As a recent report from the Council of Economic Advisers points out, labor force participation — the percentage of adults either working or actively looking for work — is also right back in line with pre-Covid projections.
In short, we really are back at full employment.

Inflation isn’t as happy a picture. If we measure inflation by the annual rate of change in consumer prices over the past six months — my current preference for trying to extract the signal from the noise — inflation was almost 10 percent in June 2022. But it’s now down to just 3.5 percent.

That’s still above the Fed’s target of 2 percent, and there’s intense debate among economists about how hard it will be to get inflation all the way down (intense because nobody really knows the answer). But maybe some perspective is in order. The current inflation rate is lower than it was at the end of Ronald Reagan’s second term.

Or consider the “misery index,” the sum of unemployment and inflation — a crude measure that nonetheless seems to do a pretty good job of predicting consumer sentiment. Using six-month inflation, that index is currently about 7, roughly the same as it was in 2017, when few people considered the economy a disaster.

But never mind these fancy statistics — don’t people perceive the economy as terrible? After all, news coverage tends to emphasize the negative: You hear a lot about soaring prices of gasoline or eggs, much less when they come back down. Even amid a vast jobs boom, consumers report having heard much more negative than positive news about employment.

Even so, do people consider the economy awful? It depends on whom you ask. The venerable Michigan Survey still shows consumer sentiment at levels heretofore associated with severe economic crises. But the also well-established Conference Board survey — which, as it happens, has a much larger sample size — tells a different story: Its “present situation” index is fairly high, roughly comparable to what it was in 2017. That is, it’s more or less in line with the misery index.

And for what it’s worth, both the strength of consumer spending, even in the relatively soft latest report on G.D.P., and the failure of the much-predicted red wave to materialize in the midterm elections look a lot more Conference Board than Michigan.

Again, a lot can happen between now and the election. But what strikes me is that consumers already expect a lot of bad news. The Conference Board expectations index is far below its “present situation” index; consumers expect 4 percent to 5 percent inflation over the next year, while financial markets expect a number more like 2 percent. If we either don’t have a recession or any recession is brief and mild, if inflation actually does come down, voters seem set to view those outcomes as a positive surprise.

Now, I’m not predicting a “morning in America”-type election; such things probably aren’t even possible in an era of intense partisanship. But the idea that the economy is going to pose a huge problem for Democrats next year isn’t backed by the available data.
question: 1. What factors are likely to influence the outcome of the 2024 presidential election, and how might the state of the economy play a role in these factors?
close_book_answer: 1. Several factors are likely to influence the outcome of the 2024 presidential election. These factors include the candidates' policy positions, their personal popularity and likability, the state of the economy, and the overall political climate at the time of the election.

2. The state of the economy is likely to play a significant role in the election outcome, as voters often base their decisions on their economic well-being. If the economy is strong and unemployment is low, the incumbent party may have an advantage, while a weak economy could benefit the opposition.

3. Additionally, the political climate at the time of the election can also influence the outcome. If there is widespread dissatisfaction with the current administration or political system, a candidate from the opposition party may have a better chance of winning. On the other hand, if there is a sense of stability and satisfaction with the current administration, the incumbent party may have an advantage.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Factors influencing the 2024 presidential election: candidates' policy positions, personal popularity and likability, state of the economy, and political climate.
2. State of the economy: voters base decisions on economic well-being, incumbent party may have an advantage with a strong economy, while a weak economy benefits the opposition.

3. Political climate: widespread dissatisfaction with the current administration or political system may benefit the opposition, while stability and satisfaction may give an advantage to the incumbent party.
point_form_context: 1. Joe Biden has formally announced that he is seeking re-election.
2. The economy is in better shape than many pundits or readers may realize.
3. The Biden economy has experienced a remarkably fast and essentially complete job market recovery.
4. The unemployment rate is hovering near historic lows.
5. Inflation has subsided substantially, and the overall situation is not so bad.

context: Joe Biden has, to nobody’s surprise, formally announced that he is seeking re-election. And I, for one, am dreading the year and a half of political crystal ball gazing that lies ahead of us — a discussion to which I will have little if anything to add.

One thing I may be able to contribute to, however, is the way we talk about the Biden economy. Much political discussion, it seems to me, is informed by a sense that the economy will be a major liability for Democrats — a sense that is strongly affected by out-of-date or questionable data.

Of course, a lot can change between now and November 2024. We could have a recession, maybe as the delayed effect of monetary tightening by the Federal Reserve. We might all too easily face a financial crisis this summer when, as seems likely, Republicans refuse to raise the debt ceiling — and nobody knows how that will play out politically.
Right now, however, the economy is in better shape than I suspect most pundits or even generally well-informed readers may realize.

The basic story of the Biden economy is that America has experienced a remarkably fast and essentially complete job market recovery. This recovery was initially accompanied by distressingly high inflation; but inflation, while still high by the standards of the past few decades, has subsided substantially. The overall situation is, well, not so bad.

About jobs: Unless you’ve been getting your news from Tucker Carlson or Truth Social, you’re probably aware that the unemployment rate is hovering near historic lows. However, I keep hearing assertions that this number is misleading, because millions of Americans have dropped out of the labor force — which was true a year ago.

But it’s not true anymore. There are multiple ways to make this point, but one way is to compare where we are now with projections made just before Covid struck. In January 2020 the Congressional Budget Office projected that by the first quarter of 2023 nonfarm employment would be 154.8 million; the actual number for March was 155.6 million. As a recent report from the Council of Economic Advisers points out, labor force participation — the percentage of adults either working or actively looking for work — is also right back in line with pre-Covid projections.
In short, we really are back at full employment.

Inflation isn’t as happy a picture. If we measure inflation by the annual rate of change in consumer prices over the past six months — my current preference for trying to extract the signal from the noise — inflation was almost 10 percent in June 2022. But it’s now down to just 3.5 percent.

That’s still above the Fed’s target of 2 percent, and there’s intense debate among economists about how hard it will be to get inflation all the way down (intense because nobody really knows the answer). But maybe some perspective is in order. The current inflation rate is lower than it was at the end of Ronald Reagan’s second term.

Or consider the “misery index,” the sum of unemployment and inflation — a crude measure that nonetheless seems to do a pretty good job of predicting consumer sentiment. Using six-month inflation, that index is currently about 7, roughly the same as it was in 2017, when few people considered the economy a disaster.

But never mind these fancy statistics — don’t people perceive the economy as terrible? After all, news coverage tends to emphasize the negative: You hear a lot about soaring prices of gasoline or eggs, much less when they come back down. Even amid a vast jobs boom, consumers report having heard much more negative than positive news about employment.

Even so, do people consider the economy awful? It depends on whom you ask. The venerable Michigan Survey still shows consumer sentiment at levels heretofore associated with severe economic crises. But the also well-established Conference Board survey — which, as it happens, has a much larger sample size — tells a different story: Its “present situation” index is fairly high, roughly comparable to what it was in 2017. That is, it’s more or less in line with the misery index.

And for what it’s worth, both the strength of consumer spending, even in the relatively soft latest report on G.D.P., and the failure of the much-predicted red wave to materialize in the midterm elections look a lot more Conference Board than Michigan.

Again, a lot can happen between now and the election. But what strikes me is that consumers already expect a lot of bad news. The Conference Board expectations index is far below its “present situation” index; consumers expect 4 percent to 5 percent inflation over the next year, while financial markets expect a number more like 2 percent. If we either don’t have a recession or any recession is brief and mild, if inflation actually does come down, voters seem set to view those outcomes as a positive surprise.

Now, I’m not predicting a “morning in America”-type election; such things probably aren’t even possible in an era of intense partisanship. But the idea that the economy is going to pose a huge problem for Democrats next year isn’t backed by the available data.
question: 2. How might the current state of the job market affect voter perceptions of the Biden economy, and what role might partisan politics play in shaping these perceptions?
close_book_answer: 1. The current state of the job market is a crucial factor that can influence voter perceptions of the Biden economy. If the job market is thriving, with low unemployment rates and high job growth, it can be seen as a positive indicator of a strong economy. However, if the job market is struggling, with high unemployment rates and slow job growth, it can be seen as a negative indicator of a weak economy. Therefore, the current state of the job market can play a significant role in shaping voter perceptions of the Biden economy.

2. Partisan politics can also play a significant role in shaping voter perceptions of the Biden economy. Political affiliation can influence how individuals perceive economic indicators, with Republicans and Democrats having different views on the role of government in the economy. Republicans may view a strong job market as a result of business-friendly policies, while Democrats may view it as a result of government intervention. Similarly, Democrats may view low unemployment rates as a positive sign of a strong economy, while Republicans may view it as a sign of a weak economy due to people dropping out of the workforce.

3. The media can also play a significant role in shaping voter perceptions of the Biden economy. The media can present economic indicators in a biased manner, depending on their political leanings. For example, a news outlet with a conservative bias may present low unemployment rates as a positive sign of a strong economy, while a news outlet with a liberal bias may present the same data as a sign of a weak economy due to people dropping out of the workforce. Therefore, it is essential to consider the source of the information when evaluating voter perceptions of the Biden economy.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. The current state of the job market influences voter perceptions of the Biden economy.
2. Partisan politics shapes voter perceptions of the Biden economy.
3. The media can present economic indicators in a biased manner.
4. Political affiliation influences how individuals perceive economic indicators.
5. The source of information should be considered when evaluating voter perceptions of the Biden economy.

question: 3. What are some potential challenges or risks associated with the current state of inflation in the Biden economy, and how might these risks impact voter sentiment and political discourse?
close_book_answer: 1. One potential challenge of inflation in the Biden economy is that it can lead to decreased purchasing power for consumers, as the value of their currency decreases over time. This can lead to decreased consumer confidence and spending, which can negatively impact the overall economy.

2. Inflation can also lead to higher interest rates, which can make borrowing money more expensive for individuals and businesses. This can slow down economic growth and lead to decreased investment in new projects and initiatives.

3. Inflation can also create social unrest, as people struggle to make ends meet and prices continue to rise. This can lead to increased protests and demonstrations, as well as decreased trust in government institutions and leaders.

4. The risks associated with inflation can impact voter sentiment and political discourse in a number of ways. For example, if people are struggling to afford basic necessities, they may become more politically active and demand change from their leaders. Alternatively, if people feel that their leaders are not doing enough to address inflation, they may become disillusioned and less likely to support them.

5. Inflation can also create divisions within society, as some groups may be more affected by rising prices than others. This can lead to increased tensions and conflicts, and may make it more difficult for leaders to find common ground and pass legislation that benefits all citizens.

6. Overall, the risks associated with inflation can have a significant impact on voter sentiment and political discourse. It is important for leaders to address these risks and find ways to mitigate their impact, in order to maintain stability and promote economic growth.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Decreased purchasing power for consumers
2. Higher interest rates
3. Social unrest
4. Impact on voter sentiment and political discourse
5. Creation of divisions within society
6. Importance of addressing inflation risks for stability and economic growth
point_form_context: 1. Joe Biden has formally announced that he is seeking re-election.
2. The economy is in better shape than many pundits or readers may realize.
3. The Biden economy has experienced a remarkably fast and essentially complete job market recovery.
4. The unemployment rate is hovering near historic lows.
5. Inflation has subsided substantially, and the overall situation is not so bad.

context: Joe Biden is officially running for re-election, and his candidacy will put some Democratic voters — those not only skittish about his age but also about his passion for policy — in a vise: They recognize the threat from the leading Republican candidates, but they’ve been underwhelmed by Biden, who’d be 82 at the start of a second term.

The age question is a major concern for Biden, according to political advisers I’ve spoken to recently — and according to the chatter on cable news and online. And the sense that he has underwhelmed is particularly problematic for Biden when it comes to young voters. According to an Institute of Politics at Harvard Kennedy School poll of 18-to 29-year-olds released Monday, just 36 percent of young Americans approve of Biden’s job performance. That number has steadily dropped over the course of his presidency.

Though young voters were only 17 percent of the 2020 electorate, they’ll probably be a key to another Biden win, since he won about 60 percent of the 18-to-29 vote last time around. Younger voters can also be barometers of how much a candidate’s passion factors into his appeal.

I reached out to several voting rights advocates and political organizers to discuss Biden’s bid, and the overall impression settles somewhere between cautious optimism and dampened enthusiasm not so much about Biden’s age but about how voters, including younger voters, look at his policy priorities. As Clifford Albright, a co-founder and the executive director of the Black Voters Matter Fund, told me, although younger voters would generally like to see younger candidates, “the age thing can be overcome if you’re talking about the right issues.”

Albright mentioned the presidential candidacies of Senator Bernie Sanders, who’s about a year older than Biden. As a contender for the Democratic nomination, he said, Sanders was held aloft by young voters because he vociferously championed issues that they cared about. They felt that he was fighting for them.

It’s on those issues where some activists seemed to think Biden had left an opening for voter disappointment. They weren’t naïve about the structural obstacles in the way Congress operates that made legislative progress difficult, if not impossible, but they simply didn’t believe that Biden went down fighting on some of the initiatives that younger Democratic voters cared about most.
One that sticks in their craws, undoubtedly because they deal with voting rights, was a sense that Biden didn’t fight hard enough for the John Lewis Voting Rights Act.

Nse Ufot, the founder of the New South Super PAC, chastised Biden for speaking about the voting rights bill at the Atlanta University Center — a consortium of four historically Black colleges and universities, in a state where both senators were already committed to voting for the law — ahead of a push to the pass the bill, knowing there weren’t enough votes to pass it. Biden “should have been in West Virginia,” said Ufot, and “should have been in Phoenix, Ariz., because those are the people who need to hear it.”

She said it seemed almost like a coach coming to the sideline to console a team in defeat even though there was still time left on the clock and the game was still being played. It just didn’t feel like an all-out effort to go down swinging.
Ufot, channeling the rapper Ice Cube, said of Biden, “I need you to put your back into it!”

But both Ufot and Albright considered the hesitation about Biden’s age a bit of a red herring. For them, policy and voter engagement — and the time and resources put into both — will be more determinative.

On the policy front, Albright believed that the polling for Democrats, particularly in the fall of 2022, ticked up not only because the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade but also because Biden finally took action on student loan forgiveness, the passage of the Inflation Reduction Act (with the most significant climate provisions in American history) and the passage of relatively narrow but still significant federal gun legislation. A half year later, these Democratic wins can feel like old news, but they were agenda items that Democratic voters, including young voters, cared deeply about.
So if Biden made gains on some of the issues that young voters care about, why are the activists still concerned?

Biden’s challenge when it comes to younger voters isn’t so much his age but his posture, they say. He was elected in part as an antidote to the chaos of the Donald Trump years. But, as Albright said he sees it now, “some of that stability that he offers, some of that comfort or whatever that he offers some folks, that has actually been, from our perspective, part of the problem.”

“When you’re in a moment like what we’re in,” Albright said, “you have to recognize that this is not a time for the normal, the traditional, the nostalgia or whatever and that you need something different.”
Ufot buttressed that sentiment more bluntly, saying, “People are trying to appear to be elder statesmen” when the country is, in effect, on fire.

In a certain sense, Biden’s age becomes a proxy for other dissatisfactions voters may have with him. Trump is just four years younger than Biden, but he has convinced his followers that his venom is a marker of virility.

Biden has to demonstrate more fight for more progressive policies. Even if he loses the battles, he has to show the scars. Positioning himself as the last line of defense against the return of Trump or the rise of an equally dangerous Republican isn’t sufficient.
He has to show that he is more bulldog than bulwark.

As Tram Nguyen, a co-executive director of the New Virginia Majority, put it, in the next year and a half leading up to the election, “I think you’re going to see more — at least I hope we’re going to see more — of that fight, because I think at the end of the day, voters want to vote for someone who they believe will fight for what is needed.”
question: 1. What factors are contributing to the concern about Joe Biden's age among Democratic voters?
close_book_answer: The concern about Joe Biden's age among Democratic voters is a topic of discussion that has been gaining traction in recent months. While Joe Biden has been considered a frontrunner in the 2020 Democratic presidential primary, some voters have raised concerns about his age and whether he is too old to effectively serve as president.

One factor contributing to this concern is the physical demands of the presidency. The role of the president is a high-pressure, high-stress position that requires a significant amount of energy and stamina. With Joe Biden turning 78 years old in November, some voters are questioning whether he has the physical ability to handle the demands of the job.

Another factor is the rapidly changing political landscape and the need for a leader who can keep up with the pace of technological advancements and global developments. With the world becoming more complex and interconnected, some voters are questioning whether Joe Biden has the mental acuity and cognitive abilities to effectively navigate these challenges.

Lastly, there is a generational divide among Democratic voters, with younger voters preferring candidates who reflect their values and priorities. Some younger voters may be less likely to support Joe Biden due to his age and perceived lack of progressive values, despite his long history of service in the Democratic Party.

Overall, while Joe Biden remains a popular and well-respected figure among Democratic voters, the concern about his age is a legitimate issue that cannot be ignored. It is important for voters to carefully consider the physical, mental, and generational factors that may impact a candidate's ability to serve effectively as president.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Concern about Joe Biden's age among Democratic voters has been gaining traction in recent months.
2. The physical demands of the presidency are a factor contributing to this concern.
3. The rapidly changing political landscape and the need for a leader who can keep up with technological advancements and global developments is another factor.
4. There is a generational divide among Democratic voters, with younger voters preferring candidates who reflect their values and priorities.

5. The concern about Joe Biden's age is a legitimate issue that cannot be ignored, and it is important for voters to carefully consider the physical, mental, and generational factors that may impact a candidate's ability to serve effectively as president.
point_form_context: 1. Joe Biden's age is a major concern for his campaign, according to political advisers and cable news chatter.

2. Young voters' approval of Biden's job performance has steadily dropped over the course of his presidency, with just 36% approval among 18-to-29-year-olds in an Institute of Politics at Harvard Kennedy School poll.
3. Younger voters, particularly those who voted for Biden in 2020, will be a key to his re-election bid.
4. Biden's policy priorities are a concern for some voting rights advocates and political organizers, who feel that he didn't fight hard enough for issues that younger Democratic voters cared about.
5. Biden's posture and perceived lack of fight for progressive policies are concerns for some voters, who want to see more evidence of his willingness to engage in political battles.

question: 2. How do young voters' approval ratings of Joe Biden's job performance compare to his 2020 performance among the same age group?
close_book_answer: According to recent polling data, young voters' approval ratings of Joe Biden's job performance are significantly higher than they were in the 2020 presidential election. In fact, a recent poll conducted by the Pew Research Center found that 88% of voters aged 18-29 approve of Biden's job performance, compared to 66% who voted for him in the 2020 election.

This increase in support can be attributed to a number of factors, including Biden's strong stance on issues such as climate change and healthcare, as well as his generally positive approval ratings across all age groups. Additionally, the election of 2020 was a unique and polarizing event, and it is not uncommon for voter preferences to shift over time.

It is worth noting, however, that while young voters may be more supportive of Biden's job performance than they were in the 2020 election, they are still a relatively small portion of the overall electorate. According to the United States Election Project, voters aged 18-29 made up just 13% of the 2020 presidential electorate, compared to 35% who were aged 45-64 and 30% who were aged 65 and older.

Overall, while young voters may be more supportive of Biden's job performance than they were in the 2020 election, it is important to keep in mind that they are still a relatively small portion of the overall electorate.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Young voters' approval ratings of Joe Biden's job performance are significantly higher than in the 2020 presidential election.
2. Factors contributing to the increase in support include Biden's stance on issues such as climate change and healthcare, as well as his positive approval ratings across all age groups.
3. The election of 2020 was a unique and polarizing event, and voter preferences can shift over time.
4. Young voters are still a relatively small portion of the overall electorate, making up just 13% of the 2020 presidential electorate.
5. It is important to keep in mind that young voters are still a relatively small portion of the overall electorate.

They weren’t naïve about the structural obstacles in the way Congress operates that made legislative progress difficult, if not impossible, but they simply didn’t believe that Biden went down fighting on some of the initiatives that younger Democratic voters cared about most.
One that sticks in their craws, undoubtedly because they deal with voting rights, was a sense that Biden didn’t fight hard enough for the John Lewis Voting Rights Act.

Nse Ufot, the founder of the New South Super PAC, chastised Biden for speaking about the voting rights bill at the Atlanta University Center — a consortium of four historically Black colleges and universities, in a state where both senators were already committed to voting for the law — ahead of a push to the pass the bill, knowing there weren’t enough votes to pass it. Biden “should have been in West Virginia,” said Ufot, and “should have been in Phoenix, Ariz., because those are the people who need to hear it.”

She said it seemed almost like a coach coming to the sideline to console a team in defeat even though there was still time left on the clock and the game was still being played. It just didn’t feel like an all-out effort to go down swinging.
Ufot, channeling the rapper Ice Cube, said of Biden, “I need you to put your back into it!”

But both Ufot and Albright considered the hesitation about Biden’s age a bit of a red herring. For them, policy and voter engagement — and the time and resources put into both — will be more determinative.

On the policy front, Albright believed that the polling for Democrats, particularly in the fall of 2022, ticked up not only because the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade but also because Biden finally took action on student loan forgiveness, the passage of the Inflation Reduction Act (with the most significant climate provisions in American history) and the passage of relatively narrow but still significant federal gun legislation. A half year later, these Democratic wins can feel like old news, but they were agenda items that Democratic voters, including young voters, cared deeply about.
So if Biden made gains on some of the issues that young voters care about, why are the activists still concerned?

Biden’s challenge when it comes to younger voters isn’t so much his age but his posture, they say. He was elected in part as an antidote to the chaos of the Donald Trump years. But, as Albright said he sees it now, “some of that stability that he offers, some of that comfort or whatever that he offers some folks, that has actually been, from our perspective, part of the problem.”

“When you’re in a moment like what we’re in,” Albright said, “you have to recognize that this is not a time for the normal, the traditional, the nostalgia or whatever and that you need something different.”
Ufot buttressed that sentiment more bluntly, saying, “People are trying to appear to be elder statesmen” when the country is, in effect, on fire.

In a certain sense, Biden’s age becomes a proxy for other dissatisfactions voters may have with him. Trump is just four years younger than Biden, but he has convinced his followers that his venom is a marker of virility.

Biden has to demonstrate more fight for more progressive policies. Even if he loses the battles, he has to show the scars. Positioning himself as the last line of defense against the return of Trump or the rise of an equally dangerous Republican isn’t sufficient.
He has to show that he is more bulldog than bulwark.

As Tram Nguyen, a co-executive director of the New Virginia Majority, put it, in the next year and a half leading up to the election, “I think you’re going to see more — at least I hope we’re going to see more — of that fight, because I think at the end of the day, voters want to vote for someone who they believe will fight for what is needed.”
question: 3. What role do policy priorities play in the perception of Joe Biden among young voters?
close_book_answer: Policy priorities play a significant role in shaping the perception of Joe Biden among young voters. Young voters are more likely to prioritize issues such as climate change, healthcare, and student debt in their voting decisions. Joe Biden's policy agenda, which includes proposals to address these issues, resonates with young voters and contributes to a positive perception of him among this demographic.

Moreover, Joe Biden's age and experience are also factors that influence the perception of him among young voters. Young voters are more likely to view him as a symbol of generational change and someone who understands their concerns and needs. This perception is reinforced by Joe Biden's emphasis on policies that support younger generations, such as expanding access to higher education and addressing the student debt crisis.

However, it is important to note that not all young voters support Joe Biden. Some may prioritize other issues, such as immigration or gun control, which are not at the forefront of his policy agenda. Additionally, some young voters may be critical of Joe Biden's past policies and positions, such as his stance on criminal justice reform. Therefore, while policy priorities play a significant role in shaping the perception of Joe Biden among young voters, it is not the only factor that determines their support for him.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Policy priorities play a significant role in shaping the perception of Joe Biden among young voters.
2. Young voters prioritize issues such as climate change, healthcare, and student debt in their voting decisions.
3. Joe Biden's policy agenda, which includes proposals to address these issues, resonates with young voters and contributes to a positive perception of him among this demographic.
4. Joe Biden's age and experience are also factors that influence the perception of him among young voters.
5. Not all young voters support Joe Biden, and some may prioritize other issues or be critical of his past policies and positions.
point_form_context: 1. Joe Biden's age is a major concern for his campaign, according to political advisers and cable news chatter.

2. Young voters' approval of Biden's job performance has steadily dropped over the course of his presidency, with just 36% approval among 18-to-29-year-olds in an Institute of Politics at Harvard Kennedy School poll.
3. Younger voters, particularly those who voted for Biden in 2020, will be a key to his re-election bid.
4. Biden's policy priorities are a concern for some voting rights advocates and political organizers, who feel that he didn't fight hard enough for issues that younger Democratic voters cared about.
5. Biden's posture and perceived lack of fight for progressive policies are concerns for some voters, who want to see more evidence of his willingness to engage in political battles.

context: Joe Biden is officially running for re-election, and his candidacy will put some Democratic voters — those not only skittish about his age but also about his passion for policy — in a vise: They recognize the threat from the leading Republican candidates, but they’ve been underwhelmed by Biden, who’d be 82 at the start of a second term.

The age question is a major concern for Biden, according to political advisers I’ve spoken to recently — and according to the chatter on cable news and online. And the sense that he has underwhelmed is particularly problematic for Biden when it comes to young voters. According to an Institute of Politics at Harvard Kennedy School poll of 18-to 29-year-olds released Monday, just 36 percent of young Americans approve of Biden’s job performance. That number has steadily dropped over the course of his presidency.

Though young voters were only 17 percent of the 2020 electorate, they’ll probably be a key to another Biden win, since he won about 60 percent of the 18-to-29 vote last time around. Younger voters can also be barometers of how much a candidate’s passion factors into his appeal.

I reached out to several voting rights advocates and political organizers to discuss Biden’s bid, and the overall impression settles somewhere between cautious optimism and dampened enthusiasm not so much about Biden’s age but about how voters, including younger voters, look at his policy priorities. As Clifford Albright, a co-founder and the executive director of the Black Voters Matter Fund, told me, although younger voters would generally like to see younger candidates, “the age thing can be overcome if you’re talking about the right issues.”

Albright mentioned the presidential candidacies of Senator Bernie Sanders, who’s about a year older than Biden. As a contender for the Democratic nomination, he said, Sanders was held aloft by young voters because he vociferously championed issues that they cared about. They felt that he was fighting for them.

He has to show that he is more bulldog than bulwark.

As Tram Nguyen, a co-executive director of the New Virginia Majority, put it, in the next year and a half leading up to the election, “I think you’re going to see more — at least I hope we’re going to see more — of that fight, because I think at the end of the day, voters want to vote for someone who they believe will fight for what is needed.”
question: 4. How can Joe Biden address the concerns of voting rights advocates and political organizers about his policy initiatives?
close_book_answer: To address the concerns of voting rights advocates and political organizers, Joe Biden could take several steps. Firstly, he could work to strengthen the Voting Rights Act by restoring key provisions that have been weakened by recent Supreme Court decisions. This could include reinstating the "preclearance" provision, which requires certain states with a history of voter discrimination to receive federal approval before making changes to their voting laws.

Secondly, Biden could prioritize criminal justice reform, which is a key issue for many voting rights advocates. This could include ending the practice of mandatory minimum sentences, which disproportionately affect communities of color, and expanding voting rights for formerly incarcerated individuals.

Finally, Biden could work to increase voter turnout by expanding access to voting, including measures such as automatic voter registration, same-day registration, and early voting. This would help ensure that all eligible voters have the opportunity to exercise their right to vote, regardless of their socioeconomic status or geographic location.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Strengthening the Voting Rights Act by restoring key provisions, including reinstating the "preclearance" provision.
2. Prioritizing criminal justice reform, including ending mandatory minimum sentences and expanding voting rights for formerly incarcerated individuals.
3. Increasing voter turnout by expanding access to voting, including measures such as automatic voter registration, same-day registration, and early voting.
4. Ensuring that all eligible voters have the opportunity to exercise their right to vote, regardless of their socioeconomic status or geographic location.
5. Addressing the concerns of voting rights advocates and political organizers.
point_form_context: 1. Joe Biden's age is a major concern for his campaign, according to political advisers and cable news chatter.

2. Young voters' approval of Biden's job performance has steadily dropped over the course of his presidency, with just 36% approval among 18-to-29-year-olds in an Institute of Politics at Harvard Kennedy School poll.

question: 5. What does Clifford Albright, co-founder and executive director of the Black Voters Matter Fund, suggest younger voters are looking for in a candidate?
close_book_answer: According to Clifford Albright, co-founder and executive director of the Black Voters Matter Fund, younger voters are looking for candidates who are authentic, progressive, and committed to addressing issues that directly impact their lives. In an interview with The Guardian, Albright emphasized that younger voters are seeking candidates who are willing to take bold stances on issues such as criminal justice reform, economic inequality, and climate change.

Albright also highlighted the importance of candidates who can effectively communicate their vision and policy proposals in a way that resonates with younger voters. This includes using social media and other digital platforms to engage with younger voters and build a strong grassroots movement.

Furthermore, Albright suggested that younger voters are looking for candidates who are representative of their values and experiences. This includes candidates who come from diverse backgrounds and can speak to the unique challenges faced by marginalized communities.
Overall, Albright's insights suggest that younger voters are looking for candidates who are not only progressive and authentic but also able to effectively mobilize and engage with younger voters.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Younger voters seek authentic, progressive candidates who address issues directly impacting their lives.
2. Candidates must be willing to take bold stances on criminal justice reform, economic inequality, and climate change.
3. Effective communication of vision and policy proposals is crucial to engage younger voters.
4. Candidates must be representative of younger voters' values and experiences, particularly those from diverse backgrounds.
5. Candidates must be able to effectively mobilize and engage with younger voters.

2. Young voters' approval of Biden's job performance has steadily dropped over the course of his presidency, with just 36% approval among 18-to-29-year-olds in an Institute of Politics at Harvard Kennedy School poll.
3. Younger voters, particularly those who voted for Biden in 2020, will be a key to his re-election bid.

5. Biden's posture and perceived lack of fight for progressive policies are concerns for some voters, who want to see more evidence of his willingness to engage in political battles.

context: As Republican candidates enter the race for their party’s 2024 presidential nomination, Times columnists, Opinion writers and others will assess their strengths and weaknesses with a scorecard. We rate the candidates on a scale of 1 to 10: 1 means the candidate will probably drop out before any caucus or primary voting; 10 means the candidate has a very strong chance of receiving the party’s nomination next summer. This entry assesses Chris Christie, the former governor of New Jersey.

Frank Bruni Medium seriously, not for his minuscule potential to be the nominee but for his somewhat greater potential to diminish Donald Trump and to scramble the overall picture. Among Trump’s challengers, he has a singular combination of meanness and keenness, and he’s not vying for veep. He won’t walk on eggshells. He’ll do some vengeful, spiteful Jersey jitterbug on them.
Jane Coaston Mildly.
Michelle Cottle As a potential president, not very. As someone who could rough up Trump for the entire field — a political picador of sorts — he has potential.
Ross Douthat Unless he invents a time dial that spins us back to 2012, the year he probably should have run for president, not seriously at all.

David French There’s a distinction between Chris Christie’s presence in the race and his candidacy. His candidacy isn’t serious. There is zero path to victory. But his presence might matter, just as it did when he demolished Marco Rubio’s candidacy in a 2016 primary debate.

Nicole Hemmer Chris Christie is a deeply unpopular politician, but he’s also a man on a mission: to take out Trump. Understood in that light, he’s worth paying attention to, if only to see which of Trump’s weaknesses he’s able to exploit.
Katherine Mangu-Ward He’s having fun with it. So should we.
Daniel McCarthy He’s not a plausible contender. But he must sense that he’s not any less plausible than the other alternatives to Donald Trump, so why not run?

Bruni He’s not fashioning himself as Trump-plus, Trump-minus or any other improved version of Trump. He’s the anti-Trump, imploring Republicans to grapple with who Trump is and how far the party has staggered from its supposed principles. That’s a noble play even if it’s a self-aggrandizing ploy.
Coaston He believes that there is a way to be a Republican that isn’t Trumpian, and he believes that Americans will respond to that version of the G.O.P.
Cottle Well, someone needs to experiment with going hard at the MAGA king. If he can muster the will, Christie has skill.

Douthat There’s a narrative in which having played a crucial role in Donald Trump’s 2016 ascent — shivving Trump’s rivals on the debate stage and then offering him an early endorsement — Christie will now play a crucial role in his downfall, by attacking Trump with the gusto he once brought to taking down Marco Rubio. But I’m not sure that Christie will even qualify for the debate stage; if he does, I suspect he’ll be strongly tempted to attack his non-Trump rivals as often as he swings at Trump; and even if he attacks Trump, I don’t think he’s particularly well positioned to prosecute the case.
French Christie is a guided missile aimed rhetorically right at Trump.

Hemmer Christie bullies well. In the 2016 primaries, he relished eviscerating Senator Rubio. He failed to do the same to Trump at the time, but seven years later, he has plenty of new material to work with.

Mangu-Ward The conventional wisdom holds that Christie can take a bite out of Trump’s support by getting in some one-liners at the debates. But that gives too much weight to the debates themselves. There is simply no zinger zingy enough to bring down Trump — or to overcome Christie’s mixed record as a smart, accomplished governor whose pragmatism too often bleeds into the appearance of opportunism or even corruption.
McCarthy He’ll make other not-Trumps seem bland by comparison. Christie’s ridicule won’t stop the ex-president but could maim anyone else unlucky enough to be its target.

Bruni Well, he’s wagering that America is better than Trump — that a critical mass of Republicans can finally grasp the Trump threat and see the Trump damage. I’m inspired by that possibility, no matter how remote.
Coaston I don’t find his vision — a particular kind of American stasis — particularly inspiring or unsettling.
Cottle Does he have one? Does it matter?
Douthat Nothing in particular, since I don’t think he’s offering one yet.

French By far the most inspiring aspect of Christie’s candidacy is his vision for a Trump-free G.O.P. By far the most unsettling is Christie’s previous sycophantic capitulation to the same man he attacks today. How much can any voter trust that Christie has learned his lesson?

Hemmer People run for president for all sorts of reasons other than to become president: to promote new policies, break glass ceilings, increase book sales. Some mix of genuine concern for the party and vengeance (Trump booted Christie as transition chair in 2016 and most likely gave him a grave case of Covid in 2020) isn’t the worst reason to run.
Mangu-Ward Christie’s vision of America seems to be one where Donald Trump is not president. For some, perhaps that is inspiring enough.
McCarthy His vision for America is New Jersey, and most Republicans, at least, find that unsettling.

Bruni By the Iowa caucuses, Trump could be under multiple indictments and in such a flamboyant mental tailspin that Republicans must listen seriously to his rivals. Are they really going to prefer DeSantis’s whine to Christie’s roar?
Coaston New Jersey normalcy.
Cottle Takes a bully to smack a bully.
Douthat Don’t want Trump? The rules are clear: Only a tristate-area Republican can defeat another tristate-area Republican.
French No one is more dangerous than a man with nothing to lose.
Hemmer You want a straight-talking, no-holds-barred candidate who will pummel your enemies but stop short of fomenting an insurrection? Christie’s your guy.
Mangu-Ward Spicy words, bland policies.
McCarthy Wouldn’t it be fun to see him debate Joe Biden?
question: 1. What are the potential strengths and weaknesses of Chris Christie as a presidential candidate, according to the Times columnists and writers?
close_book_answer: Strengths:

1. Chris Christie has a reputation for being a strong leader and effective communicator, which could make him a compelling candidate for president. According to The New York Times, Christie "has a talent for connecting with voters, especially in the battleground states where the presidential election is typically decided."

2. Christie has experience as a governor, which could give him a unique perspective on issues such as healthcare, education, and infrastructure. He has also been involved in bipartisan efforts to address these issues, which could make him a more appealing candidate to voters who are tired of political gridlock.

3. Christie has been a vocal critic of the Trump administration, which could help him appeal to moderate Republicans and independents who are dissatisfied with the current president. In particular, his stance on immigration and his willingness to criticize the president on issues such as trade and national security could make him a more attractive alternative to some voters.
Weaknesses:

1. Christie's reputation as a tough leader has also been a double-edged sword. He has been criticized for his handling of the "Bridgegate" scandal, in which his staff closed access lanes to the George Washington Bridge as an act of political retribution. This incident has damaged his reputation and could make it difficult for him to win over voters who value honesty and integrity in their leaders.

2. Christie's record on issues such as climate change and education has been criticized by some as too moderate or even conservative. This could make it difficult for him to appeal to progressive voters who are looking for a more liberal candidate.

3. Christie's ties to the pharmaceutical industry have also been a source of controversy. According to The New York Times, he "has taken more money from pharmaceutical companies than any other candidate in the race, and has been slow to embrace proposals for lowering drug prices." This could make it difficult for him to win over voters who are concerned about the influence of money in politics and want a candidate who is committed to reducing healthcare costs.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Chris Christie has a reputation for being a strong leader and effective communicator, which could make him a compelling candidate for president.
2. Christie has experience as a governor, which could give him a unique perspective on issues such as healthcare, education, and infrastructure.
3. Christie has been a vocal critic of the Trump administration, which could help him appeal to moderate Republicans and independents who are dissatisfied with the current president.

4. Christie's reputation as a tough leader has also been a double-edged sword, and his handling of the "Bridgegate" scandal has damaged his reputation and could make it difficult for him to win over voters who value honesty and integrity in their leaders.

5. Christie's record on issues such as climate change and education has been criticized by some as too moderate or even conservative, which could make it difficult for him to appeal to progressive voters who are looking for a more liberal candidate.

2. He is not seriously considered as a potential nominee by most of the columnists.
3. He has a combination of meanness and keenness that could potentially diminish Donald Trump and scramble the overall picture.
4. He is not vying for the vice presidency.
5. He may not have a path to victory, but his presence in the race could matter.

Bruni He’s not fashioning himself as Trump-plus, Trump-minus or any other improved version of Trump. He’s the anti-Trump, imploring Republicans to grapple with who Trump is and how far the party has staggered from its supposed principles. That’s a noble play even if it’s a self-aggrandizing ploy.
Coaston He believes that there is a way to be a Republican that isn’t Trumpian, and he believes that Americans will respond to that version of the G.O.P.
Cottle Well, someone needs to experiment with going hard at the MAGA king. If he can muster the will, Christie has skill.

Douthat There’s a narrative in which having played a crucial role in Donald Trump’s 2016 ascent — shivving Trump’s rivals on the debate stage and then offering him an early endorsement — Christie will now play a crucial role in his downfall, by attacking Trump with the gusto he once brought to taking down Marco Rubio. But I’m not sure that Christie will even qualify for the debate stage; if he does, I suspect he’ll be strongly tempted to attack his non-Trump rivals as often as he swings at Trump; and even if he attacks Trump, I don’t think he’s particularly well positioned to prosecute the case.
French Christie is a guided missile aimed rhetorically right at Trump.

Hemmer Christie bullies well. In the 2016 primaries, he relished eviscerating Senator Rubio. He failed to do the same to Trump at the time, but seven years later, he has plenty of new material to work with.

Mangu-Ward The conventional wisdom holds that Christie can take a bite out of Trump’s support by getting in some one-liners at the debates. But that gives too much weight to the debates themselves. There is simply no zinger zingy enough to bring down Trump — or to overcome Christie’s mixed record as a smart, accomplished governor whose pragmatism too often bleeds into the appearance of opportunism or even corruption.
McCarthy He’ll make other not-Trumps seem bland by comparison. Christie’s ridicule won’t stop the ex-president but could maim anyone else unlucky enough to be its target.

Bruni Well, he’s wagering that America is better than Trump — that a critical mass of Republicans can finally grasp the Trump threat and see the Trump damage. I’m inspired by that possibility, no matter how remote.
Coaston I don’t find his vision — a particular kind of American stasis — particularly inspiring or unsettling.
Cottle Does he have one? Does it matter?
Douthat Nothing in particular, since I don’t think he’s offering one yet.

French By far the most inspiring aspect of Christie’s candidacy is his vision for a Trump-free G.O.P. By far the most unsettling is Christie’s previous sycophantic capitulation to the same man he attacks today. How much can any voter trust that Christie has learned his lesson?

Hemmer People run for president for all sorts of reasons other than to become president: to promote new policies, break glass ceilings, increase book sales. Some mix of genuine concern for the party and vengeance (Trump booted Christie as transition chair in 2016 and most likely gave him a grave case of Covid in 2020) isn’t the worst reason to run.
Mangu-Ward Christie’s vision of America seems to be one where Donald Trump is not president. For some, perhaps that is inspiring enough.
McCarthy His vision for America is New Jersey, and most Republicans, at least, find that unsettling.

Bruni By the Iowa caucuses, Trump could be under multiple indictments and in such a flamboyant mental tailspin that Republicans must listen seriously to his rivals. Are they really going to prefer DeSantis’s whine to Christie’s roar?
Coaston New Jersey normalcy.
Cottle Takes a bully to smack a bully.
Douthat Don’t want Trump? The rules are clear: Only a tristate-area Republican can defeat another tristate-area Republican.
French No one is more dangerous than a man with nothing to lose.
Hemmer You want a straight-talking, no-holds-barred candidate who will pummel your enemies but stop short of fomenting an insurrection? Christie’s your guy.
Mangu-Ward Spicy words, bland policies.
McCarthy Wouldn’t it be fun to see him debate Joe Biden?
