context: MIAMI — There was no fanfare, no live broadcast, no backdrop of uniformed schoolchildren to cheer him on. At 11:27 p.m. on April 13, hours after the closed-door ceremony, Gov. Ron DeSantis’s office sent out an email with the subject line: “Governor DeSantis Signs Two Bills.” One was titled Causes of Action Based on Improvements to Real Property; the other was one of the most restrictive abortion laws in the country, effectively banning abortion after six weeks.

Early the next morning, Mr. DeSantis left Tallahassee to resume his book tour and deliver a speech at Liberty University in Virginia, the conservative Christian bastion of anti-abortion activism. Even there, he couldn’t find the nerve to mention his Heartbeat Protection Act.

Mr. DeSantis knows that banning abortion isn’t popular. The issue has been a losing one for Republicans in races across the country since Roe v. Wade was overturned last June. And according to a 2022 poll by Florida Atlantic University, 67 percent of Florida voters want abortion to be legal in most cases and only 12 percent support an outright ban. But as the governor prepares to run for president, he needs to keep hard-right primary voters satisfied.

As I watched all this unfold, I couldn’t help noting the contrast between the governor’s seeming desire to hide the abortion bill out of sight with the way some of the most ardent supporters of the law make their position known.

The billboards were one of the first things I noticed when my family and I moved to Central Florida in 2021. We drove around the state a lot, and as we made our way through the sprawl of the Miami suburbs, across the upper reaches of the Everglades where a river of grass transitions to a sea of sugar cane, through the citrus groves of aptly named towns like Frostproof and Fruitland Park, I was struck by the number of anti-abortion billboards we passed on the roadside.

Some are simple messages meant to induce shame, with pseudoscientific statistics and cute baby pictures. Many offer a friendly face and a phone number for a religious counseling center. All are stark and jarring against the powder-blue Florida sky.

Recently, I set out on a road trip to document some of the many billboards standing in the empty parking lots of long-forgotten motels and strip clubs. I sought out the signs that loom over early morning commuters at corner gas stations and provide a little extra income for the Pentecostal churches and boarded-up restaurants that host them. Along quiet country roads, they keep the cows and crows company; on bustling, strip-mall-lined boulevards they jockey for attention with an alarming number of ads for personal injury lawyers.

Right now, a woman in Florida is about a half-hour drive, on average, from a place where she can get an abortion after six weeks of pregnancy, according to research by Caitlin Myers, an economist at Middlebury College. When the bill that Mr. DeSantis signed last week goes into effect, that drive will, for most women, take over nine hours, much of it along these very highways. It’s a long road ahead.
question: 1. What are the implications of Governor DeSantis signing a restrictive abortion law while knowing that it is not popular among voters?
close_book_answer: 1. The implications of Governor DeSantis signing a restrictive abortion law while knowing that it is not popular among voters are significant. By signing the law, Governor DeSantis is prioritizing his own political beliefs over the wishes of the majority of voters in Florida. The divisive nature of the issue of abortion can lead to increased tension and hostility between those on opposite sides of the debate, potentially resulting in a breakdown of civil discourse and a decline in political cooperation.

This is a serious concern for the health and well-being of women in Florida and should be taken into account when evaluating the implications of Governor DeSantis' decision.

context: MIAMI — There was no fanfare, no live broadcast, no backdrop of uniformed schoolchildren to cheer him on. At 11:27 p.m. on April 13, hours after the closed-door ceremony, Gov. Ron DeSantis’s office sent out an email with the subject line: “Governor DeSantis Signs Two Bills.” One was titled Causes of Action Based on Improvements to Real Property; the other was one of the most restrictive abortion laws in the country, effectively banning abortion after six weeks.

Early the next morning, Mr. DeSantis left Tallahassee to resume his book tour and deliver a speech at Liberty University in Virginia, the conservative Christian bastion of anti-abortion activism. Even there, he couldn’t find the nerve to mention his Heartbeat Protection Act.

Mr. DeSantis knows that banning abortion isn’t popular. The issue has been a losing one for Republicans in races across the country since Roe v. Wade was overturned last June. And according to a 2022 poll by Florida Atlantic University, 67 percent of Florida voters want abortion to be legal in most cases and only 12 percent support an outright ban. But as the governor prepares to run for president, he needs to keep hard-right primary voters satisfied.

As I watched all this unfold, I couldn’t help noting the contrast between the governor’s seeming desire to hide the abortion bill out of sight with the way some of the most ardent supporters of the law make their position known.

The billboards were one of the first things I noticed when my family and I moved to Central Florida in 2021. We drove around the state a lot, and as we made our way through the sprawl of the Miami suburbs, across the upper reaches of the Everglades where a river of grass transitions to a sea of sugar cane, through the citrus groves of aptly named towns like Frostproof and Fruitland Park, I was struck by the number of anti-abortion billboards we passed on the roadside.

Some are simple messages meant to induce shame, with pseudoscientific statistics and cute baby pictures. Many offer a friendly face and a phone number for a religious counseling center. All are stark and jarring against the powder-blue Florida sky.

Recently, I set out on a road trip to document some of the many billboards standing in the empty parking lots of long-forgotten motels and strip clubs. I sought out the signs that loom over early morning commuters at corner gas stations and provide a little extra income for the Pentecostal churches and boarded-up restaurants that host them. Along quiet country roads, they keep the cows and crows company; on bustling, strip-mall-lined boulevards they jockey for attention with an alarming number of ads for personal injury lawyers.

Right now, a woman in Florida is about a half-hour drive, on average, from a place where she can get an abortion after six weeks of pregnancy, according to research by Caitlin Myers, an economist at Middlebury College. When the bill that Mr. DeSantis signed last week goes into effect, that drive will, for most women, take over nine hours, much of it along these very highways. It’s a long road ahead.
question: 2. How does the use of billboards to promote anti-abortion messages differ from the way Governor DeSantis chose to sign the bill?
close_book_answer: The use of billboards to promote anti-abortion messages is a common tactic used by anti-abortion activists to raise awareness and sway public opinion.
However, the way Governor DeSantis chose to sign the bill is different from this approach.
Governor DeSantis chose to sign the bill in private, without any media coverage or fanfare, which is in contrast to the public nature of billboards.
This approach suggests that the Governor may have been aware of the controversial nature of the bill and did not want to draw unnecessary attention to it.
Additionally, the use of billboards is often criticized for being manipulative and emotionally charged, whereas Governor DeSantis' approach was more measured and professional.
Overall, while both approaches aim to promote a certain message, the way they are executed can have a significant impact on their effectiveness and reception..

2. Governor DeSantis signed the bill in private, without media coverage or fanfare.
3. Governor DeSantis' approach was more measured and professional than billboards.
4. The use of billboards is often criticized for being manipulative and emotionally charged.
5. The way a message is executed can impact its effectiveness and reception.

question: 3. What are the potential consequences of the new abortion law on women's access to reproductive healthcare in Florida?
close_book_answer: The new abortion law in Florida has the potential to greatly impact women's access to reproductive healthcare. This law places restrictions on abortion access, including banning the procedure after six weeks of pregnancy, before many women even know they are pregnant. This restriction is particularly harmful to low-income women and women of color, who are already disproportionately affected by barriers to reproductive healthcare.

Additionally, the law requires medical professionals to perform procedures that go against their moral or religious beliefs, which could lead to a shortage of providers willing to perform abortions. This could make it even more difficult for women to access safe and legal abortion services. Furthermore, the law may also increase the risk of self-induced abortion, which is both dangerous and illegal.

In conclusion, the new abortion law in Florida has the potential to greatly restrict women's access to reproductive healthcare and may even put women's lives at risk. It is important to consider the potential consequences of such laws and work towards policies that prioritize women's health and autonomy.

4. The law may increase the risk of self-induced abortion, which is both dangerous and illegal.
5. The law has the potential to greatly restrict women's access to reproductive healthcare and may even put women's lives at risk.

context: Only 47 percent of Democrats want to see Joe Biden on the ballot in 2024, according to the latest Associated Press poll. That’s not because they think he’s done a bad job in office. Democrats tend to like President Biden and continue to give him good marks on handling the economy and foreign policy.

But many Democrats, particularly younger ones, are worried that he will simply be too old to be effective in a second term, which would end when he is 86. “My problem with him running in 2024 is that he’s just so old,” one Democrat told pollsters.

That may be deeply unfair — people age at different rates — and in Mr. Biden’s case, it’s impossible to deny that politics and conspiracy theories, rather than facts, fuel at least some of the concern. But candidates shouldn’t pretend, as Mr. Biden often does, that advanced age isn’t an issue. Mr. Biden is 80 now, the oldest American to serve as president, and even supporters, including the political strategist David Axelrod, have expressed deep worries that his age will be both a political liability in 2024 and a barrier to a successful second term. If Mr. Biden runs again, as he recently said he intends to, questions will persist about his age until he does more to assure voters that he is up to the job.

Mr. Biden’s age makes him an outlier even in an era when the nation’s political leadership is getting older. The current Senate, where the average age is 63.9 years, is the second oldest since 1789. The House, where the average age is 57.5 years, is the third oldest. By comparison, the average age in the United States is 38.8 years.

Concerns about age — both in terms of fitness for office and being out of touch with the moment — are legitimate, as Mr. Biden acknowledged in an interview in February with ABC News. His standard line, repeated in that interview, is: “The only thing I can say is, ‘Watch me.’”
But Mr. Biden has given voters very few chances to do just that — to watch him — and his refusal to engage with the public regularly raises questions about his age and health.

The usual White House method of demonstrating a president’s mastery is to take tough questions in front of cameras, but Mr. Biden has not taken advantage of that opportunity, as The Times reported on Friday. He has held fewer news conferences and media interviews than most of his modern predecessors. Since 1923, only Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan took fewer questions per month from reporters, and neither represents a model of presidential openness that Mr. Biden should want to emulate. His reticence has created an opening for critics and skeptics.

The president also needs to talk about his health openly and without embarrassment, and to end the pretense that it doesn’t matter. Those who are watching him with an open mind have seen a strong performance this year. His State of the Union address on Feb. 7 shattered the Republican attempts to portray him as doddering. With a passion rarely seen at one of these speeches — let alone in his political history — Mr. Biden presented a remarkably effective defense of his presidency and gave a preview of what is likely to be an imminent re-election campaign.

The Times reported last summer that Mr. Biden’s overall energy level has declined, and he continues to stumble over words in his public appearances. But those flaws alone don’t signal a politician who is too old to run again. His first term, in fact, is already full of accomplishment: The economy has added 12.6 million jobs since he took office, inflation is cooling, and he has signed significant legislation to fight climate change, improve access to health care, and make investments in manufacturing and infrastructure. He has stood up to Russia’s destructive campaign in Ukraine, and rallied the West to Ukraine’s side.

Nonetheless, as Mr. Biden nears his actuarial life expectancy, concerns about his ability to handle the demands of campaigning and a potential second term are unlikely to disappear. Only a combination of performance and complete candor will change the minds of skeptical voters. Old age remains a sensitive topic, and many people, particularly men, are reluctant to discuss personal infirmities for fear of demonstrating weakness or being pushed aside by impatient younger generations. There is good reason for the federal government’s prohibition of age discrimination in employment — a protection that begins at age 40. Ageism is real.

That law, however, doesn’t apply to people who are running for office. Voters have every right to ask questions about the medical condition of a candidate who wants their support. In 2016 both Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton gave the public very few details about their health. (Mr. Trump released a particularly preposterous doctor’s letter claiming he would be “the healthiest individual ever elected to the presidency.”)

Mr. Biden acknowledged during the lead-up to the 2020 campaign that he was “chronologically” old but said it was up to voters to decide whether that was important. In that election, against an opponent who was only four years younger, the answer was clearly no. In November 2021, he released a medical report that said he was a “healthy, vigorous 78-year-old” and noted nothing more serious than a stiffened gait due to spinal changes and some acid reflux that caused him to cough.

His most recent health summary, released on Feb. 16, said much the same thing, describing him as a “healthy, vigorous 80-year-old male who is fit to successfully execute the duties of the presidency.” But his cognitive abilities went unmentioned. That’s something he should discuss publicly and also demonstrate to the voters, who expect the president to reflect the nation’s strength.

If he runs again, Mr. Biden will need to provide explicit reassurance to voters; many of them have seen family members decline rapidly in their 80s. Americans are watching what Mr. Biden says and does, just as he has asked them to do.
question: 1. What factors contribute to the concern among Democrats about President Biden's age and ability to serve a second term?
close_book_answer: 1. One factor contributing to concerns about President Biden's age and ability to serve a second term among Democrats is his advanced age, which raises questions about his physical and mental fitness to lead the country.
2. Another factor is the potential impact of his age on his ability to effectively lead and manage the country's affairs, particularly in a rapidly changing political and global landscape.

3. Additionally, concerns about President Biden's age and ability to serve a second term may also stem from the desire among Democrats to ensure a smooth and seamless transition of power, particularly in light of the recent turmoil in the White House.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. President Biden's advanced age raises questions about his physical and mental fitness to lead the country.
2. His age may impact his ability to effectively lead and manage the country's affairs in a rapidly changing political and global landscape.
3. Concerns about his age may stem from the desire among Democrats to ensure a smooth and seamless transition of power.
4. The recent turmoil in the White House may also contribute to these concerns.
5. The potential impact of President Biden's age on his ability to serve a second term is a concern among Democrats.

question: 2. How does the average age of political leadership in the United States compare to the rest of the population, and what implications does this have for the 2024 election?
close_book_answer: The average age of political leadership in the United States has been a topic of discussion in recent years. According to a study by the Congressional Research Service, the average age of members of Congress has been steadily increasing, with the average age of senators being 62 and the average age of representatives being 58 in 2021. This is significantly higher than the national average age of 38.7 years old.

The implications of this age gap are significant for the 2024 election. With an older political leadership, there is a risk of a disconnect between the concerns and priorities of younger generations and the policies being implemented. This could lead to a lack of representation for younger voters and a lack of innovation in policy-making.

Furthermore, the age gap between political leaders and the general population could also lead to a lack of diversity in perspectives and experiences. A political leadership that is largely made up of older individuals may not have the same understanding of the challenges faced by younger generations, such as student loan debt, climate change, and technology-driven job displacement.

To address this issue, it is important for younger individuals to become more involved in the political process and seek out opportunities to run for office. Additionally, political leaders should actively seek out and incorporate the perspectives of younger generations to ensure that their concerns are being heard and addressed.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. The average age of political leadership in the United States has been increasing.
2. The average age of senators is 62 and the average age of representatives is 58 in 2021.
3. The average age of members of Congress has been steadily increasing.
4. The age gap between political leaders and the general population could lead to a lack of diversity in perspectives and experiences.
5. Younger individuals should become more involved in the political process and seek out opportunities to run for office.

But candidates shouldn’t pretend, as Mr. Biden often does, that advanced age isn’t an issue. Mr. Biden is 80 now, the oldest American to serve as president, and even supporters, including the political strategist David Axelrod, have expressed deep worries that his age will be both a political liability in 2024 and a barrier to a successful second term. If Mr. Biden runs again, as he recently said he intends to, questions will persist about his age until he does more to assure voters that he is up to the job.

Mr. Biden’s age makes him an outlier even in an era when the nation’s political leadership is getting older. The current Senate, where the average age is 63.9 years, is the second oldest since 1789. The House, where the average age is 57.5 years, is the third oldest. By comparison, the average age in the United States is 38.8 years.

Concerns about age — both in terms of fitness for office and being out of touch with the moment — are legitimate, as Mr. Biden acknowledged in an interview in February with ABC News. His standard line, repeated in that interview, is: “The only thing I can say is, ‘Watch me.’”
But Mr. Biden has given voters very few chances to do just that — to watch him — and his refusal to engage with the public regularly raises questions about his age and health.

The usual White House method of demonstrating a president’s mastery is to take tough questions in front of cameras, but Mr. Biden has not taken advantage of that opportunity, as The Times reported on Friday. He has held fewer news conferences and media interviews than most of his modern predecessors. Since 1923, only Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan took fewer questions per month from reporters, and neither represents a model of presidential openness that Mr. Biden should want to emulate. His reticence has created an opening for critics and skeptics.

The president also needs to talk about his health openly and without embarrassment, and to end the pretense that it doesn’t matter. Those who are watching him with an open mind have seen a strong performance this year. His State of the Union address on Feb. 7 shattered the Republican attempts to portray him as doddering. With a passion rarely seen at one of these speeches — let alone in his political history — Mr. Biden presented a remarkably effective defense of his presidency and gave a preview of what is likely to be an imminent re-election campaign.

The Times reported last summer that Mr. Biden’s overall energy level has declined, and he continues to stumble over words in his public appearances. But those flaws alone don’t signal a politician who is too old to run again. His first term, in fact, is already full of accomplishment: The economy has added 12.6 million jobs since he took office, inflation is cooling, and he has signed significant legislation to fight climate change, improve access to health care, and make investments in manufacturing and infrastructure. He has stood up to Russia’s destructive campaign in Ukraine, and rallied the West to Ukraine’s side.

Nonetheless, as Mr. Biden nears his actuarial life expectancy, concerns about his ability to handle the demands of campaigning and a potential second term are unlikely to disappear. Only a combination of performance and complete candor will change the minds of skeptical voters. Old age remains a sensitive topic, and many people, particularly men, are reluctant to discuss personal infirmities for fear of demonstrating weakness or being pushed aside by impatient younger generations. There is good reason for the federal government’s prohibition of age discrimination in employment — a protection that begins at age 40. Ageism is real.

That law, however, doesn’t apply to people who are running for office. Voters have every right to ask questions about the medical condition of a candidate who wants their support. In 2016 both Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton gave the public very few details about their health. (Mr. Trump released a particularly preposterous doctor’s letter claiming he would be “the healthiest individual ever elected to the presidency.”)

Mr. Biden acknowledged during the lead-up to the 2020 campaign that he was “chronologically” old but said it was up to voters to decide whether that was important. In that election, against an opponent who was only four years younger, the answer was clearly no. In November 2021, he released a medical report that said he was a “healthy, vigorous 78-year-old” and noted nothing more serious than a stiffened gait due to spinal changes and some acid reflux that caused him to cough.

His most recent health summary, released on Feb. 16, said much the same thing, describing him as a “healthy, vigorous 80-year-old male who is fit to successfully execute the duties of the presidency.” But his cognitive abilities went unmentioned. That’s something he should discuss publicly and also demonstrate to the voters, who expect the president to reflect the nation’s strength.

If he runs again, Mr. Biden will need to provide explicit reassurance to voters; many of them have seen family members decline rapidly in their 80s. Americans are watching what Mr. Biden says and does, just as he has asked them to do.
question: 3. What role does President Biden's reticence to engage with the public play in fueling concerns about his age and health?
close_book_answer: 1. President Biden's reticence to engage with the public may contribute to concerns about his age and health by giving the impression that he is not fully committed to the demands of the presidency.
2. The lack of public engagement may also fuel concerns about President Biden's health by raising questions about his ability to handle the physical and mental demands of the presidency.

3. Furthermore, President Biden's reticence to engage with the public may reinforce negative stereotypes about older people being less capable and less engaged, which could further fuel concerns about his age and health.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. President Biden's reticence to engage with the public may contribute to concerns about his age and health.
2. The lack of public engagement may fuel concerns about President Biden's health and ability to handle the physical and mental demands of the presidency.
3. President Biden's reticence to engage with the public may reinforce negative stereotypes about older people being less capable and less engaged.

question: 4. How can President Biden address concerns about his age and health to reassure voters that he is fit to serve a second term?
close_book_answer: 1. President Biden can address concerns about his age and health by releasing detailed medical records, undergoing a thorough physical examination by an independent physician, and committing to regular updates on his health throughout his presidency.
2. He can also demonstrate his fitness for office by presenting a robust policy agenda for his second term and showing his ability to effectively lead and manage the executive branch of government.

3. Finally, President Biden can engage in proactive communication with the American people, addressing any concerns they may have about his age and health, and emphasizing his experience, wisdom, and commitment to serving the country.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. President Biden can release detailed medical records and undergo a thorough physical examination by an independent physician to address concerns about his age and health.
2. He can demonstrate his fitness for office by presenting a robust policy agenda for his second term and showing his ability to effectively lead and manage the executive branch of government.

3. President Biden can engage in proactive communication with the American people to address any concerns they may have about his age and health and emphasize his experience, wisdom, and commitment to serving the country.

context: In their forthcoming book, “Beyond Doubt: The Secularization of Society,” the sociologists Isabella Kasselstrand, Phil Zuckerman and Ryan Cragun describe a change in the built environment of St. Louis that is “emblematic” of the ebb of organized religious observance in America. What was once a Gothic-style beauty of a Catholic church built in the 19th century by German immigrants had been turned into a skateboard park.

“In the United States,” the authors tell us, “somewhere between 6,000 and 10,000 churches close down every year, either to be repurposed as apartments, laundries, laser-tag arenas, or skate parks, or to simply be demolished.” (I’d be remiss if I didn’t mention that my apartment was once the rectory of a church, also built in the 1800s and transformed, a couple of decades ago, into condos for yuppies who want dramatic windows and a hint of ecclesiastical flavor.)

It’s not just the frequency of churchgoing or temple membership that’s declining in our country: Last month, The Wall Street Journal and NORC at the University of Chicago surveyed around 1,000 American adults about the importance of different values to Americans, including the importance of religion. In 2023, only 39 percent of respondents said religion was very important to them, compared to 62 percent who said that in 1998.

When you look at the full results, the picture becomes a bit more complicated. Sixty percent of respondents said that religion was either somewhat or very important to them, and only 19 percent said religion was not important to them at all. The United States is still a more religiously observant country than our peer nations in Western Europe — according to Pew Research in 2018, for example, we are more likely to believe in God or some kind of higher power and more likely to pray daily.

But two things can be true at the same time, said Mark Chaves, a professor of sociology at Duke Divinity School who directs the National Congregations Study: America can still be a comparatively observant nation and religious observance can be on the decline in various dimensions, happening at different paces, Chaves explains. “The decline in religious belief and interest is much slower than the decline in organizational participation,” he said when we spoke.

For example, few Americans say they don’t believe in God at all, and while that minority has grown, it’s still very small. According to NORC data, atheists only made up about 2 percent to 3 percent of the population from 1988 to 2012. By 2021, atheists were 7 percent of the population. In 1988, 17 percent of Americans said they never attended religious services. In 2021, that number was 31 percent.

Religion’s meaning to people goes well beyond regular attendance at a local church, temple or mosque, or trust in religious leaders. That’s why polling questions don’t always capture the whole picture of American religious observance. There’s been a lot of coverage about the rise of what pollsters sometimes call “nones” — people who say they have no religion in particular, which, according to Gallup, went from 0 percent to 2 percent of the population in the early 1950s to plateauing at around 20 percent of the population from 2017 to 2022.

But it would be incorrect to say that nones don’t retain any trappings of religious observance, like belief in a higher power or performing certain rituals. It doesn’t even mean they never attend church. As Zuckerman, one of the authors of “Beyond Doubt” and a professor at Pitzer College, explained to me over the phone, when social scientists talk about religion, they do it in terms of “the three B’s: belief, behavior and belonging.” If someone asks you about your religion and you say you don’t have any, Zuckerman said, “that tells me nothing about your beliefs, and that tells me nothing about your behavior. It just tells me how you identify.”

Since I started reporting this story, I’ve been asking members of my unobservant family what they’d say if a pollster asked them what their religious affiliations are. (Aware of the caveat that both sociologists I talked to noted: Responses are often shaped by how the question is asked.)

None of us have set foot in a temple or church in years. My mother and I both said we would identify as Jewish. My father — who has two Jewish parents and was bar mitzvahed — said he’d identify as “nothing” and instead likes to joke about erecting a statue of Athena in his yard. My husband, who was baptized Episcopalian but didn’t always go to church regularly growing up, said he would identify as Christian. My 10-year-old said she didn’t know what she would say. These responses, especially my dad’s and my husband’s, were surprising to me.

Because this topic is so much more complicated than “Americans used to be religious and now we’re not,” I’m making this the first newsletter in a series where I’ll explore the contours of our current relationship with religion, and try to unpack how we got here and what’s changed over the past several decades.

My goal: to inject some nuance and specificity into this discussion, since I feel like it can be and sometimes is dominated by partisans who want to argue that the decline in religiosity is either uniformly good or bad for society. My own feeling is one of profound ambivalence. I have no interest in going back to temple and little trust or appetite for organized religion. But I feel passionately about being Jewish, and a little heartsick about not knowing quite how to pass along my ritual and history to my children. I do wonder about what may be lost by not having a community connected by belief, but I’m not quite sure what that is, or if replacing it is possible, or even desirable.

I’d like to hear from you. If you were once observant or religious and are less so now, and would like to share your experience, please answer the questions in the form below. I may reach out to you for future installments of this newsletter.
“How big is this T. rex you are worried will get you while you sleep?” I asked my 3-year-old.
“As big as the house,” he cried.
“Well, that’s good,” I replied, “he won’t be able to fit through your door, then.”
The kid nodded, and went to sleep.
— Jill Quandt, Omaha

question: 1. How has the decline in religious observance affected American society?
close_book_answer: The decline in religious observance in American society has had several significant effects. Firstly, it has contributed to a breakdown in social norms and values, leading to an increase in moral relativism and a decline in community cohesion. With fewer people attending religious services, there is less of a shared sense of purpose and moral framework that can bind communities together.

Secondly, the decline in religious observance has coincided with a rise in social and economic inequality. Religious institutions have historically provided a vital safety net for the poor and marginalized, offering food, shelter, and other forms of support. With the decline in religious observance, these services have become less available, exacerbating existing social and economic inequalities.

Finally, the decline in religious observance has also contributed to a sense of spiritual malaise and existential uncertainty. Religious belief and practice can provide a sense of meaning and purpose in life, and without these, many individuals may feel lost or adrift. This can lead to increased rates of mental health issues such as depression and anxiety.

In conclusion, the decline in religious observance has had a range of negative effects on American society, contributing to social fragmentation, economic inequality, and spiritual malaise. It is important that policymakers and community leaders work to address these issues and find ways to support and strengthen religious institutions and their role in society.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Decline in religious observance has contributed to a breakdown in social norms and values, leading to an increase in moral relativism and a decline in community cohesion.
2. Fewer people attending religious services has resulted in less shared sense of purpose and moral framework that can bind communities together.

3. The decline in religious observance has coincided with a rise in social and economic inequality, as religious institutions have historically provided a vital safety net for the poor and marginalized.
4. With the decline in religious observance, services such as food, shelter, and other forms of support have become less available, exacerbating existing social and economic inequalities.

5. The decline in religious observance has also contributed to a sense of spiritual malaise and existential uncertainty, leading to increased rates of mental health issues such as depression and anxiety.

question: 2. What factors contribute to the decline in religious participation in the United States?
close_book_answer: 1. The decline in religious participation in the United States can be attributed to a number of factors, including the rise of secularism, changing social attitudes, and the increasing diversity of religious beliefs.

2. One significant factor contributing to the decline in religious participation is the growing secularism in American society. As people become more educated and exposed to diverse ideas, they are increasingly likely to question traditional religious beliefs and practices.

3. Additionally, changing social attitudes and lifestyles have contributed to the decline in religious participation. With the rise of individualism and the emphasis on personal autonomy, people are increasingly turning away from organized religion and seeking spiritual fulfillment in other ways.

4. Moreover, the increasing diversity of religious beliefs in the United States has also played a role in the decline in religious participation. As people are exposed to a wider range of religious beliefs and practices, they may become disillusioned with their own tradition and seek out new spiritual paths.

5. In conclusion, the decline in religious participation in the United States is a complex phenomenon that can be attributed to a variety of factors, including secularism, changing social attitudes, and religious diversity. Understanding these factors can help us better understand the role of religion in contemporary American society.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Factors contributing to the decline in religious participation in the US: secularism, changing social attitudes, religious diversity.
2. Growing secularism in American society contributes to the decline in religious participation.
3. Changing social attitudes and lifestyles contribute to the decline in religious participation.
4. Increasing diversity of religious beliefs in the US contributes to the decline in religious participation.
5. The decline in religious participation is a complex phenomenon with multiple factors.

What was once a Gothic-style beauty of a Catholic church built in the 19th century by German immigrants had been turned into a skateboard park.

“In the United States,” the authors tell us, “somewhere between 6,000 and 10,000 churches close down every year, either to be repurposed as apartments, laundries, laser-tag arenas, or skate parks, or to simply be demolished.” (I’d be remiss if I didn’t mention that my apartment was once the rectory of a church, also built in the 1800s and transformed, a couple of decades ago, into condos for yuppies who want dramatic windows and a hint of ecclesiastical flavor.)

It’s not just the frequency of churchgoing or temple membership that’s declining in our country: Last month, The Wall Street Journal and NORC at the University of Chicago surveyed around 1,000 American adults about the importance of different values to Americans, including the importance of religion. In 2023, only 39 percent of respondents said religion was very important to them, compared to 62 percent who said that in 1998.

When you look at the full results, the picture becomes a bit more complicated. Sixty percent of respondents said that religion was either somewhat or very important to them, and only 19 percent said religion was not important to them at all. The United States is still a more religiously observant country than our peer nations in Western Europe — according to Pew Research in 2018, for example, we are more likely to believe in God or some kind of higher power and more likely to pray daily.

But two things can be true at the same time, said Mark Chaves, a professor of sociology at Duke Divinity School who directs the National Congregations Study: America can still be a comparatively observant nation and religious observance can be on the decline in various dimensions, happening at different paces, Chaves explains. “The decline in religious belief and interest is much slower than the decline in organizational participation,” he said when we spoke.

For example, few Americans say they don’t believe in God at all, and while that minority has grown, it’s still very small. According to NORC data, atheists only made up about 2 percent to 3 percent of the population from 1988 to 2012. By 2021, atheists were 7 percent of the population. In 1988, 17 percent of Americans said they never attended religious services. In 2021, that number was 31 percent.

Religion’s meaning to people goes well beyond regular attendance at a local church, temple or mosque, or trust in religious leaders. That’s why polling questions don’t always capture the whole picture of American religious observance. There’s been a lot of coverage about the rise of what pollsters sometimes call “nones” — people who say they have no religion in particular, which, according to Gallup, went from 0 percent to 2 percent of the population in the early 1950s to plateauing at around 20 percent of the population from 2017 to 2022.

But it would be incorrect to say that nones don’t retain any trappings of religious observance, like belief in a higher power or performing certain rituals. It doesn’t even mean they never attend church. As Zuckerman, one of the authors of “Beyond Doubt” and a professor at Pitzer College, explained to me over the phone, when social scientists talk about religion, they do it in terms of “the three B’s: belief, behavior and belonging.” If someone asks you about your religion and you say you don’t have any, Zuckerman said, “that tells me nothing about your beliefs, and that tells me nothing about your behavior. It just tells me how you identify.”

Since I started reporting this story, I’ve been asking members of my unobservant family what they’d say if a pollster asked them what their religious affiliations are. (Aware of the caveat that both sociologists I talked to noted: Responses are often shaped by how the question is asked.)

None of us have set foot in a temple or church in years. My mother and I both said we would identify as Jewish. My father — who has two Jewish parents and was bar mitzvahed — said he’d identify as “nothing” and instead likes to joke about erecting a statue of Athena in his yard. My husband, who was baptized Episcopalian but didn’t always go to church regularly growing up, said he would identify as Christian. My 10-year-old said she didn’t know what she would say. These responses, especially my dad’s and my husband’s, were surprising to me.

Because this topic is so much more complicated than “Americans used to be religious and now we’re not,” I’m making this the first newsletter in a series where I’ll explore the contours of our current relationship with religion, and try to unpack how we got here and what’s changed over the past several decades.

My goal: to inject some nuance and specificity into this discussion, since I feel like it can be and sometimes is dominated by partisans who want to argue that the decline in religiosity is either uniformly good or bad for society. My own feeling is one of profound ambivalence. I have no interest in going back to temple and little trust or appetite for organized religion. But I feel passionately about being Jewish, and a little heartsick about not knowing quite how to pass along my ritual and history to my children. I do wonder about what may be lost by not having a community connected by belief, but I’m not quite sure what that is, or if replacing it is possible, or even desirable.

I’d like to hear from you. If you were once observant or religious and are less so now, and would like to share your experience, please answer the questions in the form below. I may reach out to you for future installments of this newsletter.
“How big is this T. rex you are worried will get you while you sleep?” I asked my 3-year-old.
“As big as the house,” he cried.
“Well, that’s good,” I replied, “he won’t be able to fit through your door, then.”
The kid nodded, and went to sleep.
— Jill Quandt, Omaha

question: 3. How has the rise of "nones" impacted American religious landscape?
close_book_answer: The rise of "nones" refers to the growing number of individuals who identify as having no religious affiliation. This trend has had a significant impact on the American religious landscape, challenging traditional religious institutions and shaping the way Americans understand and practice religion.

One way the rise of "nones" has impacted American religious landscape is by creating a more diverse religious environment. As individuals who identify as "nones" grow in number, they bring with them new beliefs, practices, and values that contribute to the pluralism of American religious life. This has led to the emergence of new religious movements and the revitalization of existing ones, providing Americans with a wider range of religious options.

Another way the rise of "nones" has impacted American religious landscape is by creating a more secular society. As more individuals choose to identify as "nones," the overall level of religious commitment in American society has declined. This has led to a shift in the role of religion in American public life, with religious values and beliefs playing a smaller role in political discourse and policy-making.

Finally, the rise of "nones" has also impacted American religious landscape by challenging traditional religious institutions. As more individuals choose to identify as "nones," religious institutions have had to adapt to a changing religious landscape. This has led to a decline in religious affiliation and attendance, as well as a shift in the focus of religious institutions towards social and community service.
In conclusion, the rise of "nones" has had a significant impact on the American religious landscape, creating a more diverse, secular, and adaptive religious environment.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. The rise of "nones" refers to the growing number of individuals who identify as having no religious affiliation.
2. The trend has had a significant impact on the American religious landscape, challenging traditional religious institutions and shaping the way Americans understand and practice religion.
3. The rise of "nones" has created a more diverse religious environment by bringing new beliefs, practices, and values that contribute to the pluralism of American religious life.
4. It has also created a more secular society by declining the overall level of religious commitment in American society.

5. The rise of "nones" has challenged traditional religious institutions, leading to a decline in religious affiliation and attendance, as well as a shift in the focus of religious institutions towards social and community service.

question: 4. What role does belief, behavior, and belonging play in understanding American religious observance?
close_book_answer: Belief, behavior, and belonging are key factors in understanding American religious observance. Belief refers to an individual's personal convictions and faith in a higher power or deity. In America, religious beliefs are diverse and encompass a wide range of denominations and practices. Behavior, on the other hand, refers to the outward expression of one's beliefs through rituals, practices, and observances. American religious observance is often characterized by regular attendance at religious services, participation in communal activities, and adherence to religious norms and values.

Belonging is another crucial element in understanding American religious observance. Religion can provide a sense of community and belonging for individuals, particularly in a society that is becoming increasingly diverse and fragmented. Religious communities offer a sense of shared identity, social support, and meaning, which can be particularly important for individuals who may feel isolated or disconnected from mainstream society.

In conclusion, belief, behavior, and belonging are all essential in understanding American religious observance. These factors are interrelated and play a crucial role in shaping an individual's religious identity and practice. By examining these factors, we can gain a better understanding of the complex relationship between religion and society in America.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Belief, behavior, and belonging are key factors in understanding American religious observance.
2. Belief refers to an individual's personal convictions and faith in a higher power or deity.
3. American religious beliefs are diverse and encompass a wide range of denominations and practices.
4. Behavior refers to the outward expression of one's beliefs through rituals, practices, and observances.

5. Religious communities offer a sense of shared identity, social support, and meaning, which can be particularly important for individuals who may feel isolated or disconnected from mainstream society.

question: 5. How has the repurposing of former religious buildings impacted the built environment of American cities?
close_book_answer: 1. The repurposing of former religious buildings in American cities has led to the preservation of historical structures and cultural heritage. Many of these buildings, such as churches and synagogues, were constructed during a time when religion played a significant role in society, and their architecture reflects this. By repurposing these buildings for new uses, such as museums, libraries, and apartments, the historical and cultural significance of these structures can be preserved for future generations.

2. The repurposing of former religious buildings has also contributed to the revitalization of urban areas. These buildings are often located in neighborhoods that have undergone significant changes or have experienced economic decline. By repurposing these structures, they can serve as a catalyst for revitalization, attracting new businesses, residents, and tourists to the area.

3. Additionally, the repurposing of former religious buildings has provided new opportunities for community engagement and cultural exchange. Many of these buildings have become hubs for community activities, such as art exhibitions, music performances, and community events. By creating these spaces, former religious buildings have become places where people from different backgrounds and cultures can come together and share their experiences.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Repurposing of former religious buildings preserves historical structures and cultural heritage.
2. Repurposing contributes to the revitalization of urban areas.
3. Repurposing provides new opportunities for community engagement and cultural exchange.

context: The resurgence of Donald Trump in the 2024 primary polls, the unsurprising evidence that his supporters will stand by him through a prosecution and the tentativeness of Ron DeSantis’s precampaign have combined to create a buzz that maybe DeSantis shouldn’t run at all. It’s been whispered by nervous donors, shouted by Trump’s supporters and lately raised by pundits of the left and right.

Thus the liberal Bill Scher, writing in The Washington Monthly, argues that Trump looks too strong, that there isn’t a clear-enough constituency for DeSantis’s promise of Trumpism without the florid drama and that if DeSantis runs and fails, he’s more likely to end up “viciously humiliated,” like Trump’s 2016 rivals, than to set himself up as the next in line for 2028.

Then from the right, writing for The Spectator, Daniel McCarthy channels Niccolò Machiavelli to argue that while DeSantis probably will run, he would be wiser to choose a more dogged, long-term path instead — emphasizing “virtu” rather than chasing Fortune, to use Machiavelli’s language. In 2024 Trump might poison the prospects of any G.O.P. candidate who beats him, while Joe Biden could be a relatively potent incumbent. But if the Florida governor continues to build a record of conservative accomplishment in his home state, “2028 would offer a well-prepared DeSantis a clear shot.”

I think they’re both wrong and that if DeSantis has presidential ambitions he simply has to run right now, notwithstanding all of the obstacles that they identify. My reasoning depends both on the Fortune that McCarthy invokes and on an argument that Scher’s piece nods to while rejecting: the idea that presidential candidates are more likely to miss their moment — as Chris Christie did when he passed on running in 2012, as Mario Cuomo did for his entire career — than they are to run too early and suffer a career-ending rebuke.

It’s true that Fortune doesn’t always favor the bold. (As McCarthy notes, that phrase originates in Virgil’s “Aeneid,” where it’s uttered by an Italian warlord just before he gets killed.) But the key to the don’t-miss-your-moment argument is that when it comes to something as difficult as gaining the presidency, mostly Fortune doesn’t favor anybody. All would-be presidents, no matter their virtues as politicians, are inevitably hostage to events, depending on unusual synchronicities to open a path to the White House.

A great many successful political careers never have that path open at all. A minority have it open in the narrowest way, where you can imagine threading needles and rolling lucky sixes all the way to the White House. Only a tiny number are confronted with a situation where they seem to have a strong chance, not just a long-shot possibility, before they even announce their candidacy.

That’s where DeSantis sits right now. The political betting site PredictIt places his odds of being elected president in 2024, expressed as a share price, at 23 cents, slightly below Trump’s and well below Biden’s, but far above everybody else’s. Those odds, representing a roughly 20 percent chance at the White House, sound about right to me. If you look at national polls since Trump’s indictment, DeSantis’s support has dipped only slightly; if you look at polls of early primary states, he’s clearly within striking distance, Trump has a floor of support but also a lot of voters who aren’t eager to rally to him (his indictment may have solidified support, but it didn’t make his numbers soar), and DeSantis has not yet even begun to campaign. He’s in a much better position than any of Trump’s rivals ever were in 2016, and you could argue that he starts out closer to the nomination than any Republican candidate did in 2008 or 2012.

Not to run now is to throw this proximity away, in the hopes of starting out even closer four years hence. But DeSantis’s current position is itself a creation of unusual political good fortune. Yes, he’s been skillful, but that skill wouldn’t have gotten him here without events beyond anyone’s control — the Covid-19 pandemic, the woke revolution in liberal institutions, the split between Mike Pence and Trump after Jan. 6, the strength of the Florida economy and more.

It’s obviously possible to imagine a future where Fortune continues to favor DeSantis and he goes into 2028 as the prohibitive favorite. But time and chance are cruel, and there are many more paths where events conspire against him and he wakes up in 2027 staring at PredictIt odds of 5 percent instead.

If he were at 5 percent odds right now — if Trump were leading him 75 to 20 in New Hampshire and Iowa rather than roughly 40 to 30 or if Biden’s approval ratings stood at 70 percent instead of 43 percent — I would buy the argument for waiting.
But DeSantis today is a man already graced by Fortune. And even if the goddess doesn’t always favor boldness, she takes a stern view of those to whom favor is extended who then refuse the gift.
question: 1. What factors contribute to the resurgence of Donald Trump in the 2024 primary polls?
close_book_answer: 1. The resurgence of Donald Trump in the 2024 primary polls can be attributed to several factors. Firstly, his ability to effectively mobilize his base of supporters, who remain loyal to him despite his controversial policies and actions. This base of support is crucial in primary elections, where party loyalty and ideological purity are highly valued.

2. Additionally, Trump's ability to dominate the news cycle and generate headlines through his controversial statements and actions has helped to keep his name in the public consciousness. This has allowed him to maintain a high level of name recognition and recognition among Republican voters, which is an important factor in primary elections.

3. Finally, Trump's ability to effectively use social media to reach voters and disseminate his message has been a key factor in his resurgence. This has allowed him to bypass traditional media outlets and directly communicate with his supporters, helping to maintain his momentum in the primary polls.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Trump's ability to mobilize his base of supporters
2. Trump's ability to generate headlines and maintain name recognition
3. Trump's use of social media to reach voters and disseminate his message
point_form_context: 1. Donald Trump's resurgence in the 2024 primary polls has created a buzz that maybe DeSantis shouldn’t run at all.
2. Trump's supporters will stand by him through a prosecution, and Ron DeSantis's precampaign has been tentative.
3. There is a debate among pundits of the left and right about whether DeSantis should run in 2024.
4. Bill Scher argues that Trump looks too strong, and there isn't a clear-enough constituency for DeSantis's promise of Trumpism without the florid drama.
5. Daniel McCarthy channels Niccolò Machiavelli to argue that DeSantis should choose a more dogged, long-term path instead and emphasize "virtu" rather than chasing Fortune.

context: The resurgence of Donald Trump in the 2024 primary polls, the unsurprising evidence that his supporters will stand by him through a prosecution and the tentativeness of Ron DeSantis’s precampaign have combined to create a buzz that maybe DeSantis shouldn’t run at all. It’s been whispered by nervous donors, shouted by Trump’s supporters and lately raised by pundits of the left and right.

Thus the liberal Bill Scher, writing in The Washington Monthly, argues that Trump looks too strong, that there isn’t a clear-enough constituency for DeSantis’s promise of Trumpism without the florid drama and that if DeSantis runs and fails, he’s more likely to end up “viciously humiliated,” like Trump’s 2016 rivals, than to set himself up as the next in line for 2028.

Then from the right, writing for The Spectator, Daniel McCarthy channels Niccolò Machiavelli to argue that while DeSantis probably will run, he would be wiser to choose a more dogged, long-term path instead — emphasizing “virtu” rather than chasing Fortune, to use Machiavelli’s language. In 2024 Trump might poison the prospects of any G.O.P. candidate who beats him, while Joe Biden could be a relatively potent incumbent. But if the Florida governor continues to build a record of conservative accomplishment in his home state, “2028 would offer a well-prepared DeSantis a clear shot.”

I think they’re both wrong and that if DeSantis has presidential ambitions he simply has to run right now, notwithstanding all of the obstacles that they identify. My reasoning depends both on the Fortune that McCarthy invokes and on an argument that Scher’s piece nods to while rejecting: the idea that presidential candidates are more likely to miss their moment — as Chris Christie did when he passed on running in 2012, as Mario Cuomo did for his entire career — than they are to run too early and suffer a career-ending rebuke.

It’s true that Fortune doesn’t always favor the bold. (As McCarthy notes, that phrase originates in Virgil’s “Aeneid,” where it’s uttered by an Italian warlord just before he gets killed.) But the key to the don’t-miss-your-moment argument is that when it comes to something as difficult as gaining the presidency, mostly Fortune doesn’t favor anybody. All would-be presidents, no matter their virtues as politicians, are inevitably hostage to events, depending on unusual synchronicities to open a path to the White House.

A great many successful political careers never have that path open at all. A minority have it open in the narrowest way, where you can imagine threading needles and rolling lucky sixes all the way to the White House. Only a tiny number are confronted with a situation where they seem to have a strong chance, not just a long-shot possibility, before they even announce their candidacy.

That’s where DeSantis sits right now. The political betting site PredictIt places his odds of being elected president in 2024, expressed as a share price, at 23 cents, slightly below Trump’s and well below Biden’s, but far above everybody else’s. Those odds, representing a roughly 20 percent chance at the White House, sound about right to me. If you look at national polls since Trump’s indictment, DeSantis’s support has dipped only slightly; if you look at polls of early primary states, he’s clearly within striking distance, Trump has a floor of support but also a lot of voters who aren’t eager to rally to him (his indictment may have solidified support, but it didn’t make his numbers soar), and DeSantis has not yet even begun to campaign. He’s in a much better position than any of Trump’s rivals ever were in 2016, and you could argue that he starts out closer to the nomination than any Republican candidate did in 2008 or 2012.

Not to run now is to throw this proximity away, in the hopes of starting out even closer four years hence. But DeSantis’s current position is itself a creation of unusual political good fortune. Yes, he’s been skillful, but that skill wouldn’t have gotten him here without events beyond anyone’s control — the Covid-19 pandemic, the woke revolution in liberal institutions, the split between Mike Pence and Trump after Jan. 6, the strength of the Florida economy and more.

It’s obviously possible to imagine a future where Fortune continues to favor DeSantis and he goes into 2028 as the prohibitive favorite. But time and chance are cruel, and there are many more paths where events conspire against him and he wakes up in 2027 staring at PredictIt odds of 5 percent instead.

If he were at 5 percent odds right now — if Trump were leading him 75 to 20 in New Hampshire and Iowa rather than roughly 40 to 30 or if Biden’s approval ratings stood at 70 percent instead of 43 percent — I would buy the argument for waiting.
But DeSantis today is a man already graced by Fortune. And even if the goddess doesn’t always favor boldness, she takes a stern view of those to whom favor is extended who then refuse the gift.

close_book_answer: As an AI language model, I do not have access to current events or information beyond my knowledge cutoff date of September 2021. However, I can provide some general information on how a presidential candidate's supporters can impact their decision to run for office.

Presidential candidates often consider the support of their current or former constituents when deciding whether to run for office. Trump's supporters, in particular, have been known for their strong support of the president and his policies. If they continue to express their support for Trump and urge him to run for another term, he may feel pressure to do so.

However, it is important to note that a presidential candidate's decision to run for office is ultimately a personal one that is influenced by a variety of factors, including their own political ambitions, family considerations, and personal circumstances. While the support of his supporters may be a factor in Trump's decision to run for president in 2024, it is not the only factor that will influence his decision.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Presidential candidates consider the support of their current or former constituents when deciding whether to run for office.
2. Trump's supporters have been known for their strong support of the president and his policies.
3. If Trump's supporters continue to express their support for him and urge him to run for another term, he may feel pressure to do so.
4. A presidential candidate's decision to run for office is ultimately a personal one that is influenced by a variety of factors.
5. The support of his supporters may be a factor in Trump's decision to run for president in 2024, but it is not the only factor that will influence his decision.

question: 3. What are the potential consequences for Ron DeSantis if he decides not to run for president in 2024?

2. On the other hand, by not running for president, DeSantis may be able to focus more on his current role as governor of Florida and address issues specific to the state. This could potentially lead to positive outcomes for the people of Florida.

question: 5. What role does fortune play in the decision of a politician to run for president, and how does it impact the likelihood of success?
close_book_answer: 1. Wealth and fortune play a significant role in the decision of a politician to run for president, as it provides the resources and financial stability needed to mount a successful campaign. This is particularly true in the United States, where campaigns can be extremely expensive and require substantial funding.

2. The influence of wealth and fortune on the likelihood of success in a presidential campaign can be seen in the number of wealthy individuals who have run for and won the presidency. For example, both Donald Trump and Jeb Bush were able to self-fund their campaigns, giving them a significant advantage over their opponents.

3. However, it is important to note that while wealth and fortune can provide an advantage, they do not guarantee success. Other factors, such as charisma, policy positions, and voter appeal, also play a critical role in determining the outcome of a presidential campaign. Additionally, a candidate's ability to connect with voters and effectively communicate their message can often outweigh their financial resources.

2. Wealthy individuals have won the presidency in the US.
3. Wealth and fortune do not guarantee success in a presidential campaign.
4. Other factors such as charisma, policy positions, and voter appeal play a critical role.
5. A candidate's ability to connect with voters and communicate their message can outweigh financial resources.

context: If you have a steady job in the United States, there’s a good chance you are bound by an employment contract that sets the terms of your work, including hours, salary and benefits. But the contract’s reach may not be limited to that job. It may also contain language that puts restrictions on your life even after you leave that job.
These are noncompete clauses, the focus of the Opinion video above. They typically prevent an employee from working for a competitor for a certain period after leaving the company.

Once the domain of high-flying executives privy to trade secrets or other highly sensitive information, noncompete clauses have become the scourge of employees of all kinds. Many low-wage workers — including hairstylists, fast-food line cooks and security guards — are now burdened by them. And the limits they impose on labor mobility have become a drag on the American economy.

In a hopeful development, the Federal Trade Commission proposed a rule this year that would ban the use of noncompete clauses in future employment contracts and void such clauses in existing contracts. The commission’s three members are soliciting public feedback on the proposal.

But the commission is under tremendous pressure from the business community not to ban noncompete clauses. The video above argues that the F.T.C. should listen to workers rather than bend to the will of corporations that are abusing them.
question: 1. What are the potential consequences of noncompete clauses on the labor market and the economy?
close_book_answer: Noncompete clauses are agreements between employers and employees that restrict the employee from working for a competitor or starting a business in the same industry after leaving the company. While noncompete clauses may serve to protect a company's interests, they can have significant consequences on the labor market and the economy.

Firstly, noncompete clauses can limit worker mobility and career advancement opportunities. Employees who are subject to noncompete clauses may be prevented from taking better-paying or more fulfilling jobs in their industry, as they are restricted from working for competitors. This can lead to a decrease in job satisfaction and a lack of motivation to excel in their current position.

Secondly, noncompete clauses can contribute to a decrease in labor market competition and an increase in monopolistic practices. By limiting worker mobility, noncompete clauses can stifle innovation and creativity in the industry, as employees are less likely to switch jobs and bring new ideas and perspectives to their work. This can ultimately lead to a decrease in the quality of products and services offered by companies in the industry.

Finally, noncompete clauses can have negative economic consequences by limiting economic growth and job creation. By restricting worker mobility, noncompete clauses can limit the pool of skilled workers available to new and growing companies, making it more difficult for these companies to expand and create new jobs. Additionally, noncompete clauses can discourage entrepreneurship, as potential entrepreneurs may be deterred from starting a business in a competitive industry due to the restrictions imposed by noncompete clauses.

In conclusion, noncompete clauses can have significant consequences on the labor market and the economy. While they may serve to protect a company's interests, they can limit worker mobility, stifle innovation and creativity, and discourage entrepreneurship. It is important for policymakers to carefully consider the potential impact of noncompete clauses when making decisions about labor market regulations.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Noncompete clauses restrict employee mobility and career advancement opportunities.
2. Noncompete clauses can stifle innovation and creativity in the industry.
3. Noncompete clauses can limit the pool of skilled workers available to new and growing companies.
4. Noncompete clauses can discourage entrepreneurship.
5. Noncompete clauses can have negative economic consequences by limiting economic growth and job creation.
point_form_context: 1. Employment contracts in the US often include noncompete clauses that restrict employees from working for competitors after leaving the company.
2. Noncompete clauses have become common for employees of all kinds, including low-wage workers.
3. Noncompete clauses have negative impacts on labor mobility and the American economy.
4. The Federal Trade Commission proposed a rule to ban noncompete clauses in future employment contracts and void such clauses in existing contracts.
5. The FTC is under pressure from the business community not to ban noncompete clauses, but should listen to workers instead.

question: 3. How do noncompete clauses affect workers of different income levels and industries?
close_book_answer: Noncompete clauses, which restrict employees from leaving their current job to work for a competitor or starting a similar business, have been a topic of controversy for many years. These clauses can have significant impacts on workers of different income levels and industries.

Firstly, noncompete clauses disproportionately affect lower-income workers. These workers often have fewer job opportunities and may be forced to accept a job with a noncompete clause as a condition of employment. This can limit their ability to seek better job opportunities or to start their own businesses, leading to lower income and limited career advancement.

Secondly, noncompete clauses can also impact high-income workers, particularly in industries such as technology and finance. These workers may have valuable skills and knowledge that make them highly sought after by competitors. As a result, noncompete clauses can limit their ability to leave their current job for a better opportunity, potentially leading to lower earnings and a lack of career advancement.

Lastly, noncompete clauses can also impact industries that rely on innovation and creativity. For example, in the tech industry, companies often require employees to sign noncompete clauses to protect their intellectual property. However, these clauses can stifle innovation and make it more difficult for workers to start new companies or pursue new ideas.

In conclusion, noncompete clauses can have significant impacts on workers of different income levels and industries. These clauses can limit career advancement and earning potential, particularly for lower-income workers. Additionally, noncompete clauses can stifle innovation and limit opportunities for workers in industries that rely on creativity and innovation.

question: 4. What role do corporations play in the use of noncompete clauses, and should they be held accountable for their use?
close_book_answer: Noncompete clauses are a common feature in employment contracts, which restrict employees from working for a competitor or starting a similar business after leaving their current job. Corporations play a significant role in the use of noncompete clauses, as they often require employees to sign these clauses as a condition of employment.

The use of noncompete clauses has been a subject of controversy, with some arguing that they restrict employees' ability to seek better job opportunities and stifle innovation. Critics argue that corporations should be held accountable for their use, as they often use these clauses to maintain a monopoly in their industry and suppress competition.

On the other hand, proponents of noncompete clauses argue that they are necessary to protect a corporation's intellectual property and trade secrets. They also argue that noncompete clauses are a fair exchange for the training and support that corporations provide to their employees.

In my opinion, corporations should be held accountable for their use of noncompete clauses. While noncompete clauses may be necessary in some cases, their widespread use can have negative consequences for employees and the broader economy. Corporations should be transparent about their use of noncompete clauses and consider the impact on their employees and the industry as a whole. Additionally, governments should consider regulating the use of noncompete clauses to prevent their abuse and promote fair competition.

question: 5. What are the potential drawbacks of the Federal Trade Commission's proposed rule to ban noncompete clauses, and how might they be addressed?
close_book_answer: One potential drawback of the Federal Trade Commission's proposed rule to ban noncompete clauses is that it may lead to a decrease in employee mobility and a reduction in job opportunities. Noncompete clauses are commonly used by employers to prevent employees from leaving and joining competitors, which can limit the pool of available talent and reduce competition in the job market. By banning noncompete clauses, employees may have more freedom to move between jobs and pursue better opportunities, but this could also result in a reduction in job opportunities for workers who are unable to comply with the new rule.

Another potential drawback of the proposed rule is that it may disproportionately affect low-wage workers. Noncompete clauses are often used in industries that pay lower wages, such as retail, food service, and hospitality. By banning noncompete clauses, low-wage workers may be at a disadvantage compared to workers in higher-paying industries who are not subject to the same restrictions. This could lead to a widening of the wage gap and a decrease in economic mobility for low-wage workers.

A third potential drawback of the proposed rule is that it may lead to unintended consequences for small businesses. Noncompete clauses can be used to protect a company's intellectual property and trade secrets, which can be particularly important for small businesses that may not have the same resources as larger companies. By banning noncompete clauses, small businesses may be at a disadvantage compared to their larger competitors, which could lead to a decrease in innovation and entrepreneurship.

To address these potential drawbacks, it may be necessary to implement a more targeted approach to regulating noncompete clauses. For example, the ban could be limited to certain industries or types of employees, such as low-wage workers or high-level executives. Additionally, the ban could be accompanied by measures to support small businesses and promote economic mobility for low-wage workers, such as investing in job training programs or providing tax incentives for companies that offer good benefits and fair wages.

2. The proposed rule may disproportionately affect low-wage workers and widen the wage gap.
3. The proposed rule may lead to unintended consequences for small businesses and decrease innovation and entrepreneurship.
4. A more targeted approach to regulating noncompete clauses may be necessary to address potential drawbacks.
5. Measures to support small businesses and promote economic mobility for low-wage workers may be necessary to address potential drawbacks.
